text:
I'm curious about a couple of things about this recipe.  First, why did I end up with 24, not 12, of these mini muffins as the recipe indicates?  Could it be an AR misprint?  Mine is a standard, mini-muffin tin.  Second, I really don't like nutmeg much. So WHY do I LOVE these muffins?! And why can't I stop popping them in my mouth?  Don't kid yourself by thinking that because they're  small you won't eat as much.  You'll just eat more of them.  And making them in the mini muffin tins was GENIUS, Dianne! That way you get more of that buttery, cinnamony sweetness in every bite!  I did make a couple of modifications, but nothing that would significantly alter the recipe.  I used butter instead of margarine and, because I have an entire quart of buttermilk to use, I subbed buttermilk for the milk. This worked beautifully, but please note that if you do that you MUST add 1/2 tsp. baking soda and eliminate the baking powder to adjust the acidity and make them rise properly! Plus they're so darned pretty I could just eat them up!  (And I already did, with five of them) Your recipe is a beauty, Dianne! ~A hopefully helpful update: because of my curiosity I did some shopping around  to learn that the sizes of mini-muffin tins varies, sometimes significantly! This explains the variance in yield with this recipe, to anywhere from 12 to 24 of these little muffins.

text:
I'm the submitter of this recipe and I'd like to add a few notes!  First, the recipe should read "butter or margarine."  Either one works great.  Second, I finally found out from my mom, who got the recipe from my grandma, that this recipe makes 24 mini muffins.  You fill the muffins cups 1/2 full with batter, and they should rise to just above top of the muffin tin.  You can certainly also make 12 larger mini muffins if you wish, but "officially" this recipe makes 24.  I think 12 has worked for me because my muffin tin is on the bigger side.  Sorry about the confusion!

text:
Wonderful recipe that's a cross between a mini muffin and a donut hole!  Simple, delicious, sweet little treats that are kinda like a potato chip - I dare you to eat just one.....  With that in mind the only thing I would do differently next time is to double or triple the recipe because these don't last long. I sprayed a little Pam for baking in the bottom of my mini-muffin cups so they'd pop right out. I can't wait to make these with my niece as this is definitely a kid friendly recipe. Thanks Dianne! Update: Like others, I did get a little more than twelve out of one batch but I was so busy popping these little goodies in my mouth I didn't notice the discrepancy. And at any rate, you just can't get enough of these!

text:
I just made these this morning! They were very good! I put in a little less than 1/2 tsp of nutmeg. I also coated mine in powdered sugar, vanilla glaze and a chocolate glaze. We all like the vanilla glaze best! Here is the recipe I used for my vanilla glaze

2 cups confectioners' sugar
1 tsp vanilla extract
1 TBS milk
1 TBS butter, softened
Put that into a bowl and mix together. I added more milk, but I didn't measure. I just got it to the consistancy I liked. Once I mixed it, I poured have of the glaze into another bowl and added 1 TBS cocoa powder and mixed. Then I dipped the muffins in the glazes and let dry. I double dipped them. Then on the vanilla glaze ones, I dipped some of the tops in the chocolate glaze. Also, glaze them once they have cooled. If you don't wait, they will fall apart.

text:
okay, my two cents.  i can see where everyone thought these to be a 5 star rating, but i think the nutmeg to be a little over-powering and i am a *bigtime* spice lover!!!  in fact, i am usually heavy-handed in that dept., but followed this recipe to a 'T' and i personally thought it over the edge where the nutmeg was concerned.  also, the batter made 14 of these puppies for me, no matter how hard i pressed on the original twelve trying to duplicate the recipe as written.  it wasn't going to happen unless i was willing to accept huge, sweet, sugar-coated 'shroom-looking muffins.  lastly, the sugar/cinnamon ingredients are way over-kill.  i would easily cut the amount(s) by one third.

Oh my word are these amazing! I would give ten stars if I could. They taste just like little sugared donuts, but without all the guilt. I made these as written, but chose just to coat the tops with the margarine and sugar mixture, so I reduced the cinnamon and sugar topping by half. There was still some left over, so I'll just save it to use on the next batch, which I think I'll just make right now. Make sure you spray the pans well and they will pop out very easily. Dianne, this recipe is outstanding!

text:
Nice recipe when you don't have eggs. I didn't have nutmeg so I used pumpkin pie spice and used 1/4 tsp. I halved the butter and sugar and added a tsp of vanilla. For the topping I skipped the melted margarine and tossed them with 1 tsp cinnamon and 1/8 cup of sugar in a paper bag to coat, made 18 mini muffins baked in 18 minutes. *** I have tried it with an egg as well and we noticed no difference with taste or texture. ***

text:
Delicious! I had been craving donuts and this satisfied my sweet tooth perfectly - and presumably at least a little healthier since they're baked (not fried like actual donuts). I made the muffin recipe exactly as listed (I did sub butter instead of margarine), but baked them in regular size muffin tin using cupcake liners. The recipe as listed gave me 8 "regular" muffins. Then, instead of rolling them in the butter & cinnamon-sugar mixture I simply drizzled melted butter on the tops of the muffins & sprinkled the cinnamon sugar over the butter while they were still warm & fresh out of the oven. They were fantastic - great taste and texture - I'll definitely make these again! P.S. Since I made these in a regular size muffin tin I baked them for about 21 mins.

text:
These are absolutely delicious! I made a double batch and followed the recipe exactly. They fit perfectly into my 24 slot mini muffin pan, however, when they baked, the tops rose out of the pan, and instead of staying nice and puffy, they spread out over the muffin pan. This was not the look I wanted...so I took the edges off of the finished muffins before rolling them in the cinnamon sugar and butter. This made them look more like donut holes. I was also wondering about the rolling in butter part...I couldn't seem to do it without the muffins being absolutely soaked in butter...I ended up just dipping the tops of the rest after I dipped the first few. The taste of these muffins, however, makes up for these defects...in my opinion, they're even better than donuts. My family ate the whole double batch in about 10 minutes...and absolutely loved them. Thanks for sharing your recipe, Dianne! It's a keeper!

text:
I love the cider donuts that are available in the Fall so I tweaked these muffins to resemble them. Not a huge fan of nutmeg, I substituted cinnamon for the nutmeg in the  batter. Next time I think I will add a pinch of nutmeg along with a teaspoon of cinnamon. I also substituted cider for the milk. The result is wonderful! I did have butter left over after dipping the tops so I will melt less for that. In accordance with some other reviews, after dipping the tops, I rolled the entire muffin in the cinnamon and sugar mixture and as a result I ran out just before the last muffin! So I'll be a little heavy-handed with that next time but that's because I altered the recipe, not because the recipe was faulty. I made these little gems so that I can take some with me tomorrow to an interview for a volunteer position cooking at a local hospice. I hope they lke them as much as I do!

text:
YUM! Yes it is more like a donut than a muffin, hence the name. This recipe hits the donut craving spot!  I've never baked anything like them, and don't have a deep fryer so I've never attempted donuts before.  I have to hide these or I'd eat the whole batch! (I just baked them, they're still warm) I'm so glad I found this recipe.   I had a minor mishap but it was my own fault.  I didn't grease the muffin pans enough OR I didn't let them cool enough (?) because some of them stuck to the pan. I performed muffin surgery and got them out looking okish.  When I covered them in the sugar mixture it hid most of the boo boo's. I think I filled the pans too full, so some of the lids came off when I was trying to remove them too! grrr.   I used powdered sugar for half of them - as advised - I shook them in a bag of powdered sugar while warm. anyways- they were amazing. I'm giving the recipe 5 stars- but I'm giving myself 3 stars for the execution.  Why dock the recipe?!?

text:
9 10 11 ... http://allrecipes.com/recipe/214651/donut-muffins/ ... I had two before leaving for work & came home to a container of powdered sugar & cinnamon sugar - & two dirty minimuffin tins.  :(  :)  Yeah, good!  I guess I had the right size pans because mine made 24 exactly - no muffin tops.  :D  I baked mine about 20 minutes at 350.  They don't get very brown so don't go by looks too much.  They were just barely browning at the edges when they were done - just barely.  Margarine will give these babies a more donut taste.  Not that I have anything against butter, but it would give a more cupcake or muffin taste.  Same with adding vanilla.  Good, but donuts are pretty plain.  Good-good, but not so deep in flavor.  I used 1/8t nutmeg.  I'm not a big fan of it.  It was barely detectable.  'Probably because I knew it was there.  I didn't want to taste it, just to have good flavor.  I tried the cinnamon sugar listed.  Yummy.  Also did half white sugar, half powdered.  Yummy, too.  Gonna try adding a little cocoa to the powdered sugar ones, too.  When I get some jam, gonna try jelly filling 'em.  After that, may have to lose a few pounds.  :D ... 'Tried cocoa, not so good.

text:
AWESOME!  These definitely tasted like a cinnamon sugar donut only bite size.  I used butter as I didn't have any margarine and they were "Oh so good"!  They took such little time to make.  Hubby loved the little crunch they had.  This is the second time I've made these and they came out perfect once again.   I got 18 muffins and baked them for the full 20 minutes.  If you are afraid they will be too sweet, just dip the top and roll in the sugar mixture.  They will pick up less sugar that way.   Thank you Diane for such an AWESOME recipe!

city:

None
text:
These were absolutely delicious! I'm keeping this recipe! I've made them twice so far. 1st time: I followed the recipe exactly; however, I'll reduce the sugar (the one for coating) a BIT b/c I had some left over. I wanted it to seem like a donut so I used chocolate glaze to pour on top of the muffin. I used the glaze from this site (Sanity Chocolate Glaze). 2nd time: I really wanted to them to look like donuts so I used a measuring cup to form a circular 'cup' and poured the batter into 3 of the foil 'cups'. I didn't pour too much since they puff up. After they were done, I took them out and cut a hole in the middle of each foil muffin cup, then after I coated then, I brushed chocolate glaze! They totally looked like donuts! And were delicious!  I ADDED THREE PHOTOS of THEM to THIS RECIPE, so you can CHECK IT OUT if you wanna see how they came out :) I just wished I had sprinkles and it would have been perfect donuts!

text:
*** MUST NOTE: these puff way up when baking. I mean like they triple in volume. I was thinking the cups looked too empty, but they PUFFED big time.   To save a big mess, I just brush a decent amount of melted butter over the top of the muffins in the tins while still warm, it runs right down the sides. Then I sprinkle with the cinnamon sugar. Finally I just pick them up and dip the bottoms in the cinnamon sugar. Mine were done in like 13 minutes, so watch them closely. Thanks for a tasty recipe!

text:
I used butter instead of margerine because that's what I had on hand. I made no other changes. I got 15 mini muffins, using my small cookie scoop to make even muffins. The first batch were slightly overcooked at 17 minutes, so 15 minutes at 375* was right on for me. The kids loved these and I had one with my morning coffee and had to hold myself back from having more. This would be great to make on the weekend as I know my husband would have loved these. Thanks for sharing your recipe, Dianne. NOTE: I plan on making this again soon with the margerine. I think that is essential to get the donut flavor, so I will make this again once I have margerine and update my review.

text:
In a word, DELICIOUS!!  These tasted very much like the mini donuts you get at the fair, only no frying with these.  They are SO EASY to put together.  In under an hour I had the batter mixed up, the mini muffins baked & cooled and coated with the butter and cinnamon-sugar mixture... it could not have been faster!  I thought the nutmeg seemed perfect, but next time I may add a little cinnamon to the batter as well.  I am also curious to try adding a glaze to them.  Such a simple recipe with so many possibilities, thanks Dianne!  UPDATE 7/16/14 - Because my family loves cinnamon so much, I now use 1/2 teaspoon cinnamon and only 1/4 teaspoon of nutmeg.  I also add 1 Tablespoon of Cinnamon to the dipping mixture, instead of just 1 teaspoon.  Perfect for us!  I also started adding about 1/8 teaspoon of salt to the batter - gotta have some salt to bring out the sweet!

text:
Phenomenal recipe by Dianne.  My coworkers now refer to them as "timbits" and the recipe is oftentimes requested.

The recipe is so incredibly easy to put together.  Keep in mind to stir this by hand to avoid over-mixing ingredients.  Working with he dough too much will result in a flat hard muffin.  Stir until just blended and don't worry too much about the tiny lumps.  My only alteration to this recipe is adding a tsp of vanilla.

Thank you Dianne for the wonderful recipe.

text:
Yummm! Yep, they taste just like little donut holes! I love the nutmeg! 

The only changes I made was to add a dash or two of cinnamon and salt to the batter, and to add a bit of nutmeg and salt to the cinnamon sugar coating. I love how just a little dash of salt really brings out the flavor. I also used half whole wheat flour.

In the future, unless I'm making these for a dessert (since that really is what they taste like), I'll skip the butter coating and just dip the tops in the cinnamon sugar. It sticks perfectly fine without the butter and tastes plenty sweet and savory!

These really are amazing! I can't wait to have them on cold winter mornings with a steaming cup of cocoa! Thanks! :)

Oh.....I really loved these. I don't have a mini pan, so I doubled the recipe with ONLY 1/2 teaspoon of freshly grated nutmeg. Because of my spousal unit's diabetes, I used splenda instead of sugar in the muffin. I did however roll in real sugar and cinnamon as directed. I think the key is to lightly mix the dough so they remain tender & let them rest 5 minutes before you roll them. My changes produced 12 med muffins. This is a huge winner at our house. Thank you!

text:
I'm sorry...but I did NOT like these at all. I usually never fail at recipes, but this one I tried 2 times and both times flopped completely. In the first batch, I followed the recipe exactly. I followed the instructions exactly and that's where it went wrong. I thought that maybe this recipe isn't meant for the vigourous mixing and beater of a KitchenAid in order to result in an airy muffin, so I literally mixed the margarine and sugar in a bowl...with a spoon...a fork...a whisk. I was really skeptical at this point, but I stirred in the milk...with a spoon...and then a fork...and then a whisk...it absolutely did NOT combine and was a mess.  The second time around, I followed the recipe exactly except that I used a hand mixer. It worked great - you should change that in your instructions.  The finished product was a mushy mess that stuck to the pan, regardless of the fact that it was very well greased - I have never had this problem before. In addition, I think there is WAY too much baking powder for this amount of batter - I found the muffins to have a very strange taste...

This recipe seemed like it could have potential, but as it is....no go. sorry!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Pros: Easy to make, delicious.
Cons: Very delicate.

I wanted something I could throw together pretty quickly for breakfast and these looked great, and they taste great, but I ended up destroying about half the pan trying to get them out, and I used cooking spray! These are so delicate when they come out of the oven that setting them on the cooling rack the wrong way will end up causing a very noticeable dent. I had to wait for them to cool before I even tried to roll them in the coatings. Also, I didn't have any nutmeg on hand for the batter so I just used cinnamon. The plain muffins are quite good too, very buttery and light, perfectly good even without the coating.

My muffins didn't rise and were like little stones when they came out. I made it twice. Since so many have had success with this recipe, I can't understand what went wrong. Also, most donuts aren't that spicy. If I were to try this recipe again, I would cut the nutmeg in half, add a pinch of salt to bring out flavor and add more cinnamon to the sugar. I really like the idea of a donut muffin and will look for a different recipe.

text:
skip the dipping in butter part unless you really want the extra richness/fat.  shaking them while still warm in a bag of cinnamon sugar works just as well and these are oh so fluffy and tasty!  after the first few I actually skipped the cinnamon too and just shook them in sugar, felt the cinnamon overpowered the other flavors.
also, if you don't have a mini muffin pan, just do a little dollop at the bottom of a regular muffin pan.  they arent the same shape but they're delicious little ovals!

text:
Great recipe to have kids help with.  Simple and yummy!  Made them into chocolate by adding vanilla instead of nutmeg and 1/4 cup of cocoa.  Made a glaze of 1 cup confectioners sugar, 1 tbs butter and 1 tbs milk.  Mixed glaze and then heated in microwave for 30 seconds.  Mixed again and then dipped donut muffins in while still warm.  Kids added sprinkles and they looked great and tasted great too!  Will make again very soon.  Thanks for a great recipe Dianne!  (Keep eye on  muffins, mine were done in 12 mins.)

text:
I made these for hubby.  He likes stuff like this- I don't.  He tried one and loved it.  Then I tried one.  They are very good.  I used a brand new mini muffin tray, cooked for 17 minutes and they turned out quite dark (as compared to the photos).  I have an thermometer in my oven and baked them at exactly 375.  They were crispy on the outside and soft and delicious on the inside.  They are so tasty and cute.  They would be great to serve at a shower, brunch or any tea party type event.  Thanks for the recipe.

text:
These are delicious!!  The first time I made these I thought the nutmeg flavor was overwhelming so I cut it in half the next time but then it didn't taste like a donut anymore so I put in all the nutmeg from then on.  I also tried these with the entire muffin rolled in the butter cinnamon sugar mixture and it was WAY too much butter. We normally love butter but it took the donut flavor away for us.  I then dipped just the tops in the butter and rolled the whole thing in the cinnamon sugar mixture and it was perfect for us.  I only needed to cook mine for 10-15 min.

text:
I just made these...house smells divine! They were easy to make and so delish!  I made 12 w/strawberry preserves and 12 plain.  While the plain are good just as they are, I really love preserves in them.  Just put about 1 tsp or so of batter in muffin pan, 1/2 tsp jam, and another tsp of batter.   It doesn't matter if it looks messy.  It will bake just fine, I promise! And I AM NOT A SEASONED BAKER!! What an easy dessert for busy holidays or just an after school treat!  If you have young children, they could certainly help with the dipping!  I've already had 4! I had to see if they were done, right? lol

surelyyoujessed

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674134.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
These turned out fantastic.  I don't know what some were expecting, I mean, it is baked instead of fried.  So therefore it won't have the expected texture. I used regular sized muffin tins filled halfway, and baked for 15  minutes. they came out moist and light. Next time I may actually use mini muffin pans because I only made 11 regular sized "donuts." The only thing I changed was to add cinnamon to the batter, and brown sugar to the topping.  I rolled the donuts still warm from the oven in the cinnamon/sugar/brown sugar topping after dipping the tops in butter.  I made sure to only melt a quarter of a cup of butter at a time into a bowl, that way when I dipped the donuts, they didn't get soaked, as I noticed some reviewers said that the butter was too much.  I didn't add nutmeg as I did not have any, but the cinnamon was a good substitution.  I will happily make these again, maybe next time using powdered sugar instead. :)

These are pretty tasty little guys. The first time I made them I failed miserably. Don't know why. I did, however, find that the tinier the muffin tin the nicer they bake up. And, they don't get quite as crunchy as the 'larger' mini tin. The smaller one seemed to brown much nicer for some reason.

text:
I made these following the recipe except I used butter instead of margarine.  I really liked them better the next day.  My teenagers didn't care for them at all.  I think it was the nutmeg.  I was getting bored dipping the tops so I dumped the cooled muffins in a ziplock bag, poured the melted butter in zipped it closed and tossed gently.  Than I poured them out into a bowl, poured in the cinnamon and sugar and tossed.  they didn't break up at all!

None
country:
None
text:
I just made these and this recipe is excellent.  Using muffin pans, the recipe donut-muffin was chewy inside, but had crunchy edges outside.  We personally found the nutmeg to be a bit overpowering, and will reduce down to 1/2 tsp or less next time.   I took another reader's suggestion and rather than make the melted cinnamon sugar icing, I put 1/4 cup of sugar and 1 teaspoon of cinnamon in a brown bag.  As I pulled the donut-muffins out of their pan hot from the oven, I tossed them in the brown bag, and let the kids shake them up.  Truly delicious and fast breakfast recipe, thank you SO MUCH for posting this.

text:
I made a few minor changes with great results - I doubled the recipe and made 12 regular size muffins. I divided the batter in half and partially filled the muffin pan, added a half teaspoon of jelly and topped that with the remaining batter. And though I was tempted to do the butter and cinnamon sugar dipping after baking, I knew I would hate the sticky fingers so I just sprinkled the sugar mixture on the batter before baking. Will definitely be making these over and over again!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I have made this 3 times in a week and all I can say is HOLY DONUTS!!! If left to sit in an airtight container for 6 hours or so, these little beauties soften up and taste just like the donuts we get at the fair from the Holy donut wagon. My family really liked them the first time but loved them  after I cut the nutmeg down to 1/4 teaspoon and added 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon to the batter. I also cut the melted butter to 2 Tablespoons for dipping, it was more than enough. It only took 13 minutes to bake so watch them closely after 12 minutes.

You have muffins made of staples and you don't even need eggs. As far as plagiarism is concerned, nowdays it's very hard to find out who is the recipe "owner". Some recipes are passed from friends to friends, from mothers to daughters, who knows where the recipe came from? I would not be so severe meanly because it's just a recipe. Let's not be petty.

These were great!  I'm not a fan of nutmeg so used a little less and they were really good!  To the poster who complained that this recipe is plagiarism I think that is ridiculous!  I would venture to guess that 80%-90% of the recipes on ANY recipe site are the same as you can find anywhere else.  I know when I compare recipes I find the exact recipe on many sites and magazines.  Or maybe a tiny variation.  This is called sharing.  Nothing on here says the recipe has to be an original.  It would be a very small site if it did.  Thank you, Diane, for sharing!

text:
I made these today and i just I loved this recipe, i did add and extra 2 Tablespoon of milk as i found the batter a little too stiff. I have a mini donut pan and used that. I put the batter into a piping bag with a wide opening and piped the batter into the pan to insure even distribution. They baked in 13 minutes. I did dunk some in the cinnamon sugar but i also melted some chocolate, dipped the tops in to cover and then sprinkled some sprinkles on top of the chocolate. They looked and tasted AMAZING!!! A definite favorite in this house.

text:
The dough for this tastes ridiculously good.  It'll be a wonder if you can get the batter into the pans.  The only thing about these is that they are very tender so make certain they are completely cool and stable before dipping them in the warm butter (I avoid margerine wherever possible as it consists of the chemical compound for plastic).  I tried to follow the instructions as-is and the muffins practially exploded when dipped.  Completely cool makes a big difference.

These were excellent! Mine came out a little crisp on the bottoms - I checked them at 15 minutes and thought they could use another couple minutes.  In hindsight, I should have taken them out at 15, before they turned too golden brown.  Regardless, they are still tasty!  I used butter, and follow the recipe exactly. Next time I think I will add a pinch if nutmeg to the topping also.  Great recipe!

text:
These are so delicious for breakfast or a quick snack!  Based on some previous reviews, I wanted to share my thoughts:  first, I used some old Mirro aluminum mini pans that I found at a yard sale....the best ever, and they work better than the set of non-stick ones I own.  I used the smalled Pampered Chef scoop and the recipe yielded EXACTLY 24 mini muffins.  About the nutmeg.  If you use a high quality spice (I used Penzey's), you can get away with 1/2 tsp. of nutmeg.  If you have old or "store brand" spices, use the full amount specified in the recipe.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Boy, are these little things yummy! They DO taste like cinnamon donut holes! I used butter, not margarine, and 1-1/2 teaspoons of fresh grated nutmeg (sounds like a lot, but fresh nutmeg is fluffy, and unlike ground nutmeg.)  I made 20 mini muffins. I used 3 tablespoons of butter for the topping, it was too much. I'll use 2 tablespoons next time. I will be making these again soon! I'm also going to try them with rice flour (instead of all purpose) for a gluten-free muffin. I love that they don't have egg in them. UPDATE 5/24/11: made these with (white) rice flour this morning for a gluten-free muffin, and let me tell you, they are GREAT!

country:

text:
I would do 4 1/2 stars if I could, yum!.  Super easy and so, so tasty.  I found that my small mini muffin tins were perfect (I got more than 24 because I wanted them smaller-mine is from Pampered Chef).  You really want to fill them just to halfway so that the donuts are small and do not become mushroom-topped.  This also keeps them nicely bite-sized but watch that you do not bake them too long.  
I actually recommend baking them just to doneness and while they are yummy warm, they are SO good if done a day in advance or atleast let them sit for several hours.  Not sure why but they got better with time.  Thank you for a great treat Dianne!

text:
This didn't taste as good as I thought it would be after reading all these reviews. I was hoping that it would taste more like a donut than a muffin, but it didn't. I should've listened to the other reviews and cut down on the nutmeg. I am a fan of nutmeg, but the amount called in this recipe made it way too overpowering. I felt like I could've cut down on the sugar as well. Also, you can probably cut the cinnamon sugar mixture by half. I think if I make this again, I'll go ahead and roll the dough in the cinnamon sugar before baking - then it'll taste like a snickerdoodle muffin!

text:
Wow, I am not so sure why the rating on this recipe is so high.  I followed it to the T...  I think part of the let down came from the fact that I have used a far better recipe. This recipe has WAY too much nutmeg and without any eggs...wrong texture.  It is more like a soggy pancake than a cake donut texture.  Also, it calls for no salt so it doesn't have a strong, bold flavor...just kind of sweet blah without that dash of salt.  Won't make again, will go back to the recipe that is much better IMPO.  Thought I would give this one a try since the ratings were so high...disappointed.

userID:
893561
Display Name:
Melissa T

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674149.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I really liked these donut muffins.  They were super easy to make and quite tasty.  I will definitely be making these again.   

Based on other reviews, I did make one change to the original recipe, and I am glad that I did.  I reduced the nutmeg to 1/2 tsp.  It was perfect...if I used 3/4 tsp as the original recipe recommended, I think it would have been a bit too much.  

After my first try at these, I will probably make a few more changes the next time I make them.  I will continue to just use 1/2 tsp of nutmeg.  I will also reduce the amount of cinnamon sugar to half.  There was just too much - I still had quite a bit left over and felt that they were still way too sweet. The cinnamon sugar overpowered the taste of the donut muffins - I couldn't even taste the dough...just the cinnamon sugar.  Next time, I think that I'll just add it to the tops of the donut muffins, rather than all over.  Or, I will brush the muffins with the butter an sprinkle the cinnamon sugar on top of them.  

Also, watch the baking time.  I started with 15 minutes and it was good...20 would have been too much.  I am glad that the poster of this recipe gave a pretty decent range for the cooking time.

text:
I thought these were really good!! I had a couple minor problems... when I dipped the first one in butter, it tasted like raw dough dipped in butter and cinnamon sugar!!! So I didn't dip the rest in butter first, and then they tasted great!! I only had one muffin tin, so I tried to divide the dough into 12, but that did NOT work!!! They were overflowing to begin with!! So, when I took them out of the oven, the tops separated from the bottoms when I tried to get them out of the pan!!! So next time, I'll make more than 12, grease the pan better, and not dip them in butter!!! (oh, I also added half of the nutmeg:))

text:
In mini muffin pans, there will be a yield of between 17 and 24 muffins. I over-filled the cups and still got 17. They are yummy, and terribly easily popped in your mouth, as Paula has warned. So, heeding the warning, I used apple sauce for the muffin margarine, but used butter for the dip and dip topping. These were fast, easy, and are pretty as the pictures. I imagine the butter/margarine in the muffin would be the tastier option (as written). Thanks for posting.

country:
None
text:
I baked the first batch for my coworkers as a tester, they were so easy to make that I woke up early and whipped up a second batch before work. I think the batter needs a little more flavor for my tastes but it's yummy as is. 

My changes: I used cinnamon because I forget to buy nutmeg. With the first batch I forget to melt the butter for the batter, that produced the same end result but, the batter resembled more of a normal lumpy muffin textured batter. I have an electric oven, so I had to rescued the baking time to 15 minutes max. I generously sprayed my pan with Professional grade Pam but they kinda stuck a little, a little nudge with the pairing knife popped em right out. I kept the butter warm during the dipping process(10 seconds in the microwave), and I noticed the cinnamon/sugar mixture stuck better to the muffin. I used my mini muffin tin and ended up with 26-28 minis after filling each 1/2 way. My pan makes mini muffin/baby cupcakes(lol). My coworkers gobbled up the muffins & my sons loved them. Thanks Dianne!

I used fresh grated nutmeg and used real butter for dipping the cinnamon sugar topping for the recipe.  I cold barely even swallow without gagging.  I could taste the margarine in the batter and along with the overwhelming taste of nutmeg made it unbearable. 
I am not a novice baker and I like nutmeg. This recipe just called for too much of a good thing. I guess it could be very different with the pre-ground nutmeg, but I don't purchase nutmeg that way. Even if I used real butter in the batter and less nutmeg, I just don't think it would be worth the ingredients to make it again.

text:
I have made this recipe 3 times over the past week and a half....my family loves them!  Made regular-size muffins...a triple recipe makes 2 dozen in my pans.  Added about 1 tsp. salt plus 2 tsp. vanilla extract plus about 3/4 tsp. lemon extract to the tripled recipe - really gives them that great donut flavor.  Used stick margarine (Imperial) in the batter, but used real butter to dip the muffin tops at the end.  Took the muffins out of their paper cups for dipping and coating with the cinnamon sugar, while still warm.  Also rolled some of them in powdered sugar instead....really yummy...taste just like donuts!  So good with coffee in the morning!!

text:
Okay, I don't like donuts as a generally rule, but the other people who live with me do.  These seemed easy, and I felt like baking...and I CAN be nice, so I decided to make them tonight for breakfast in the morning.  They are incredibly easy to make, that is for sure.  So, like any good cook, I had to try my creation.  Now I am typing this with sugary fingers, after just having finished my 4th muffin!!!  I followed the recipe exactly, using butter and also freshly grated nutmeg.  I found that I only needed to bake them for about 11-12 minutes for them to get nicely browned.  I see in other reviews that some found the amount of nutmeg to be overpowering.  On the contrary, I found these muffins to be rather delicate in flavor.  They are light and airy, rather than dense.  Perfectly pop-able!  I think I will try different types of toppings, maybe a glaze.  But these are delightfully tasty just as written.  Thanks for a great recipe, Dianne :)

city:

region:

country:

text:
These were just alright. They're slightly reminiscent of a similar recipe also on AR, French Breakfast Muffins, which I like better. Used only 1/4 tsp nutmeg (a little goes a long way) and added a few shakes of cinnamon right into the batter. Anytime you bake with melted butter as opposed to softened, creamed butter, you'll get a drier, more crumbly outcome, which these muffins delivered. With a rather Bisquick-y texture, these were fine dunked in my morning coffee. My 4 year-old had no complaints, however, these probably won't be a repeat.

text:
These are tasty AS IS!  I've made these a number of times now and they are great--you don't NEED to change anything.  However, DH is diabetic, so I've made some changes based on this. I use whole wheat flour (Nutri-Blend - looks white with the goodness of Whole Wheat) and Splenda in the mix. I add cinnamon, a pinch of salt, a little vanilla and a 1/4 tsp. of baking soda to cut the taste of the bkg powder/Splenda in the mixture.  When the muffins are baked, we prefer brown sugar instead of white to roll them in.  We LOVE these!

text:
I made 2 versions of these. 

The first, was a simple maple syrup (home made)  substitute to be thematic with spring. I rubbed the warm tops with butter and sprinkled mixed cinnamon sugar over the tops from a shaker. These were a huge hit with the kids. 

For a Vegan version - I again substituted maple syrup for the sugar, but also olive oil for the butter and almond milk for the milk. They had amazing flavor but lost the donut-like consistency. They were a little more scone like, but very delicious.

text:
Love these! I made these several years ago and (I don't know how) missed the part about mini muffins (or chose to ignore that part) These are best as minis! And, there's no such thing as having too much butter (and please use real butter, don't insult them with margarine) or cinnamon sugar, you're just not dredging them enough! Roll them all around in the butter and sugar, keep re-rolling them til they won't hold any more cinnamon sugar! Yum, yum, yum!  I added about 1/4 tsp salt and 1/2 tsp vanilla also. Magnifique!!

text:
Really simple and easy. But i have to note that 15 mins @ 375 was way too long.  I pulled them out with 4 mins left and they were still overdone.  Will try 350 next time.  Might cut back the nutmeg to 1/2 tsp. and add a little cinnamon to the batter cause these really didn't need the extra butter and sugar on top! Also we made in a 24 muffin tin and there didn't seem to be enough batter.  May fill to 3/4 of the way next time and dust with powdered sugar.  One last thing the measurements for the topping are a bit excessive. I'd cut back the amounts by half or even a quarter next time as i have a bowl full of cinnamon sugar left over.  Thx for sharing!

city:

None
country:
None
text:
These are super tasty! I followed the recipe exactly, except I added a little extra fresh grated nutmeg. They definitely don't have the texture of a donut (not that I expected that, but since other people were complaining about that..) but they have a nice, tender muffin consistency. One tip - don't over mix the batter! When it says to mix until just combined, they mean it! If there are lumps and still a little flour visible, this is fine! When you over-mix muffin batter, it gets still and doesn't rise properly.

text:
To "rivercity" who gave this recipe one star because it was "plagiarized" from the Colorado Cache cookbook... Yeah, this is an original Betty Crocker recipe under the name "French Breakfast Puffs."  It's been around far, far longer than the 1990's and that cookbook...it was around by 1979 for sure, and certainly well before that.  Therefore, whoever put that in your Colorado Cache cookbook copied from Betty Crocker.  Being misinformed is not a good reason to give this recipe one star.

Back to the recipe, the original calls for 1/4 teaspoon of nutmeg instead of 3/4.  1/4 is definitely the way to go!  Otherwise, great. :)

I made this twice. One in the oven and the other time in my donut maker. I followed the recipe as close as possible but did follow the suggestions to cut down the nutmeg to 1/4 tsp. Glad I did. text:
This REALLY does taste like a donut - only not fried.  I made a double batch since I have 4 mini muffin pans and I'm glad I did.  I had more than enough to share with neighbors, son in college, and friends.  Everyone loved them.  This is a very quick and easy recipe to pull together.  To quickly coat with cinnamon and sugar I put the ingredients in a large bowl with a lid.  I dipped 6 muffins at a time and put in the bowl, put lid on, and gently swirled the bowl around.  Reuslts:  48 beautiful muffins done in about 5 minutes.  Most certainly will be making these again.  Thanks Dianne for sharing this delicious recipe!

text:
Fun to make - fun to eat! A little heavy on the nutmeg imo.
Don't get to hung up in the amount the recipe yields as the size of mini-muffin pans varies. Just fill the pan 2/3 full and you will have cute, mushroom like donut-muffins. Used margarin for the dough and butter for coating as it tastes more.

text:
Oh my goodness!! These were so yummy. The nutmeg flavor was pronounced but since I love nutmeg I thought it was great. My sister didn't know what it tasted like but she too liked the muffin. It's not too strong but can easy be subbed out with cinnamon. Some reviewers had issues with the consistency of these but I thought they were great, just like any muffin I've ever had. Believe it or not, my 3 and 5 yr. olds didn't like these. They licked the tops and left the whole muffin. That left me to eat them up. Oh darn. I mean who else is gonna eat them after they've been licked clean? I liked that this recipe came together very easily, the result was delicious, and the amount was accurate. I got exactly 24 mini muffins. I will make this again with cinnamon in place of the nutmeg for my kids.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674158.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
It seemed to me to be basically a snicker doodle in a muffin. I substituted whole wheat flour for all-purpose flour, extra virgin olive oil for margarine, and used fat free milk and about 1/3 less sugar. Also, I didn't have nutmeg, so I used cinnamon in the batter as well as in the topping. It wasn't overpowering, though suffice it to say, it produced a very pleasant aroma as it baked in the oven. For the topping for about six mini muffins, I mixed about a tablespoon of olive oil with approximately a teaspoon of sugar and a sprinkling of cinnamon. (I'm one of those measuring-averse people who likes to eyeball things when I can get away with it). In any case, it's a really great, easy recipe that requires ingredients that most people anyway have on hand.  The only thing I will do differently next time is line the muffin pans with a teaspoon of olive oil for each cup which is what I do when I make biscuits, to keep them moist as they came out a bit dry.

These are absolutely delicious!!!  I was wondering how they would be without an egg, but there were so many excellent reviews I just went ahead with the recipe.  I substituted 1/2 cup of lite sour cream for the milk, since I wanted to use it up.  And as a reviewer suggested, who had used buttermilk, I eliminated the baking powder and added 1/2 teaspoon of baking soda instead.  These are amazing!!  I used my Pampered Chef cookie scoop and it made 24 perfectly shaped mini muffins.  I also cut back on the topping ingredients by about 1/2 and it was perfect.  Excellent recipe!!

text:
These were good, but I agree with some other reviewers that it calls for too much nutmeg (and I used fresh grated, which is more mild).  I think using less would make it taste more like a donut.  I would also wait about 5 minutes before rolling them in the sugar so that the heat of the donut didn't "melt" the sugar into it.  But overall these were pretty good and very simple to make so I will make them again with the minor adjustments.

text:
These have an odd texture for a muffin, and were almost impossible to get out of the pan without crumbling.  I wonder if the addition of half an egg or so would help with that.  Unlike many reviewers, I did not find the nutmeg or butter/sugar overpowering.  In truth, I found the flavor of these muffins rather bland.  They have a pleasant taste, but neither the texture or taste is particularly doughnutty or memorable.

country:
None
text:
These were so good and easy to whip up!  I was reading the recipe last night and jumped up to make them, so they would be ready for the morning.  In the morning, I just set the even on warm and let them sit in there.  We all liked them a lot!  The do taste like the donut holes, but without all the fat and calories!

I did cut the sugar in the batter to 1/4 cup and added 1/4 cup of wheat germ. I didn't have nutmeg, so I used 1/4 tsp pumpkin pie spice and 1/2 tsp cinnamon.  And used unsweetened almond milk. They were really tasty! Everything else, I did as the recipe stated.  Oh, the batter was really thick and used a TBL to put in mini cupcake pan.  I was able to get 20 minis out of this recipe.

text:
Ok, how come mine didn't turn out like the picture?  Don't get me wrong, LOVE the taste, they are really yummy.  First batch, I followed to the letter.  They never rose up much, very low, and a bit crisp.  For the 2nd batch, I lowered the temp to 350 and did 1-1/2 times the batter and added just a touch of baking soda.  Up they they went over the top but didn't puff up, just spread.  YUMMY, really good, but I really wanted poofy little muffins!  I'll keep experimenting, they are that good to give it more and more and more tries.  My family is not complaining at all, thank you!

text:
Wow, these are a nice treat. I had heard that these were originally an Allrecipes "recipe group" pick, so I wanted to try them. I even bought a Baker's Secret 12 cup mini muffin pan to make them. With the full recipe I am able to get about 17 or 9 with half the recipe. I use low fat milk and whipped butter and they work great. I actually tried regular stick butter once and found them to be way too greasy. So, I now stick with the lower fat whipped butter version. Someone mentioned on the recipe buzz that these are also great with apple cider instead of milk. I may have to try sometime. The way I do make them they remind me of a cinnamon & sugar cake doughnut.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
These muffins were super easy to bake, but I have to agree with other reviewers...I don't think 3/4 tsp of nutmeg was necessary.  Here are a few things I thought were worth noting:

*Reduce nutmeg 1/2 tsp 
*Baking powder made muffins a bit bitter, will try reducing amount to 3/4 tsp next time
*When doubling recipe, it's not necessary to double the butter/cinnamon mixture.  
*Over-stirring the batter will produce flattened muffins.  Only mix until flour and baking powder are combined.
*The cinnamon sugar on top is key!  It MADE the muffins! :)

text:
These besically tasted like a cupcake DROWN in butter. I tasted just a plain muffin before dipping it in the butter and then cinnamon/sugar and it tasted great, but if I ever make these again, I will only brush the tops with butter and then just dip the top in cinnamon/sugar. The butter just made this way too rich and oily. An overall great concept, just needs a little tweaking.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Made these for a quick Sunday morning breakfast today. I read the reviews first, and used only about 1/8 tsp of Nutmeg and about 1/2 tsp of cinnamon. I also subbed half & half for the milk because I had some to use up before exp date. Baked for 15 mins exactly and brushed on the butter while still in the pan. I used McCormick Cinnamon & Sugar in the jar and sprinkled over the buttered tops. They came out of the mini muffin pan quite easily and they were very good.  A very easy to make quick "treat" for a weekend breakfast!  Will make these again, I am sure!

text:
These are fantastic!  How much nutmeg (or cinnamon for that matter) you use is a matter of taste...and the age of your spices.  Personally, I cut way back on the nutmeg and the truth is that I'm sure they would be great with none at all if that's what you like.  I just made these for fun, but plan on making them again next time I have guests over.  I think serving these with fresh sliced fruit would make a fantastic/light way to finish a meal.

text:
These muffins are great as is.  I'm always looking for ways to healthify things, however, so for this recipe I cut the sugar to 1/3 cup, used 1/2 cup of unsweetened applesauce instead of the butter, used 1 cup of whole wheat flour instead of all-purpose, and added 3 teaspoons of wheat bran.  I brush butter lightly on top at the end and then dip in the sugar/cinnamon mixture.

I was skeptical about this recipe since it did not include eggs, but what a surprise! It was a quick and easy late night treat. I recommend scaling back the nutmeg, I used 1/2 teaspoon and it was quite strong. Add a few dashes of cinnamon and 1/4 teaspoon vanilla to the batter for added flavor. The batter can be a bit floury tasting, so up the sugar by at least 2 tablespoons. Overall, very good!

country:
None
text:
While mixing the batter, I thought the amount of sugar called for was too high, but prepared the recipe as directed anyway (can't honestly rate the recipe if I tweak it the first time I make it).  My kids liked them, but my kids also believe sugar is a food group!  LOL!  Anyway, DH and I both thought they were way too sweet, even when we skipped the cinnamon sugar topping.  I'll stick with my original recipe for doughnut muffins;  1/3 C shortening, 1/2 C sugar, 1 egg, 1.5 C flour, 1.5 tsp baking powder, .5 tsp salt, .25 tsp nutmeg, 3/4 C milk.  The ratio of sugar to flour is lower, and the addition of salt cuts that over-sweet problem.  I also use POWDERED sugar and cinnamon for the topping, because we don't like that "gritty" feeling of chewing pure white sugar.

I have NEVER written a review for anything in my life, but I had to write one for these.  I had made mini donuts, and my family loved them so much.  I went in search of another potential recipe and found this one.  The first time I made it exactly as the recipe states (except I used butter instead of margarine).  Everyone loved them. The best part is that these are SO easy to make, and they make you look like such a great baker:)

These really deserve a 3 1/2.   In my opinion 3 means bad and 4 means good. These definitely aren't bad, they're just not phenomenal.   Ok this all sounds very negative. They're good muffins. They're just not spectacular.   This could be attributed to the fact that i made them regular sized so they had less cinnamon/sugar coating. But...I'm rating the muffins not the topping.   The consistency was wonderful. They would make a fabulous base.   Don't use margarine-the butter is what makes it.   I doubled it-the regular amounts made a pitiful amount. It made 11 regular sized muffins. And the butter/cinn/sug topping didn't need to be doubled (for some reason there's always too much).   I feel so guilty giving this a three star. They're good. They're just not "wow"! They're perfect if you want a simple muffin or a starting point.

city:

country:

text:
These are very yummy.  Making them in mini muffin tins allows the donut hole taste.  I only gave it four stars because:
1- they need to be eaten while warm, when they cool they get a little hard
2- rolling in the cinnamon sugar mixture was too sweet (for my taste), dipping in butter (yum) and then sprinkling on the mixture would be better (for me)

TIP- to make rolling in sugar quicker, I used the zeppole method: pour melted butter in a ziplock bag, toss in donuts.  Remove donuts, place in a brown lunch bag filled with cinnamon sugar or powdered sugar, give a good shake.

I finally got around to trying these today. We really liked them.  The amount of nutmeg was perfect. The only thing I did differently was to brush the tops of the muffins with butter when they came out of the oven, while they were still in the pan.  I sprinkled them with the cinnamon sugar, then took them out of the pan to cool on a wire rack. That saved MANY calories and they tasted delicious.

text:
So yummy, you do not need to change a thing!  For a different coating, try an easy orange glaze: 1/2 cup icinig sugar and 1 tbsp orange juice.  Dip the donuts in the glaze after they have cooled.  Lay on wire rack with wax paper underneath to catch the drippings.  Makes for easy clean up!   My family liked the glazed ones better.  Great recipe!

I have to admit that when I was mixing the dough, I thought it looked...not so appetizing.  I was skeptical on how the donuts would taste.  I was pleasantly surprised to say the least! city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I don't think they tasted quite like the sugar donut holes - they were actually better.  They were easy and were good, but too sweet for my tastes.  (Sugar donut holes are even more too sweet and denser.)  I kept eating the silly things, but that's just too much sweet for me.  If I make them again (I think my brother would love them, after the way he was spying the too-sweet baked goods in the grocery the other day), I would only dip the tops.  As it was, there was too much of the cin-sugar, though I accidentally found a recipe calling for some and was able to use it up.  I didn't think the nutmeg was over-powering at all - maybe the cinnamon covered it up.  Really, everything was good except for being just "too much."  Made them exactly as is, using butter inside and a spread for the tops.  Even melted the butter as it says and it worked fine.  I have 2 sizes of mini muffin pans, and I used the smaller, which is the size I see the liners in the grocery, about the size of a donut hole.  Filled them 3/4 full as it says and they puffed over the top a bit (not like a mushroom), and I got 16 of them.  My other pan is bigger, and very old that I got from my mother and I never see that size.  This was the christening of my new mini pan. :-)

text:
THERE'S NO SALT IN THIS RECIPE!!! I had my salt cellar out on the counter, ready to pinch away, but THERE'S NO SALT! You have NO idea how hard it is to find recipes as full of flavor as this one without tons of sodium  -  I am *so* grateful - bless you :).   I too used freshly grated nutmeg, so I scaled down to perhaps 1/2 a teaspoon coupled with 1/2 t of cinnamon.  Absolute perfection.  The Man of the House will be so pleased.  UPDATE & NOTE TO SELF:  *always* used liners and just dip tops - no matter what I use, my muffins always stick

text:
Wow these are so good! And very easy to make. I did only used 1/2 tsp nutmeg and added 1/4 tsp cinnamon to the batter. I don't have a mini-muffin pan so I used a normal sized muffin pan, filled each cup about 1/3 of the way which made 12 almost-mini-muffins. To cut out a lot of calories I tossed them with the cinnamon and sugar in a large ziplock while they were warm out of the oven. They were coated perfectly and turned out delicious!

These muffins or donuts are AWESOME. city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I suspect that whoever wrote this recipe doesn't have much of a background in baking. It's a cool recipe, but has some fundamental baking 101 no no's. I made them & they turned out AWESOME but only because I made the following changes. First, with such a sweet baked product like this, you gotta have some salt for balance: 1/2 a tsp to the muffin batter is perfect. Second (& this was my biggest pet peeve) in a recipe such as this where you "mix until just combined" (overmixing really messes things up), always separately mix your dry ingredients and then SIFT them into the wet. They omit these steps in the recipe which is a big mistake unless you like uneven clumps of baking powder. Other than that everything else was fine. In the batter, I decreased the nutmeg to 1/2tsp & added 3/4tsp cinnamon & felt the spices were perfectly balanced :)

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
This original recipe comes from the Betty Crocker cookbook published in the 50's or so. I don't  know the exact date. Anyway,  they are called "French Breakfast Puffs". My mom made these for special occasions.  Now, I make them for my family most Saturday mornings. I like to use a mixture of cream and milk to make them a bit fluffier. The nutmeg is crucial! It gives a subtle flavor. Leaving out nutmeg    will give you a "just ok" muffin. I make 12 regular sized muffins. Don't overcook! To get a light, fluffy muffin cook for 20 minutes.  Don't let the tops brown or the muffin will get tough. Yummy!

country:
None
text:
Made several batches of these for Easter brunch. Taste tested while they were still warm and had to resist the urge to eat several (dozen) more. They are SO GOOD. The only change to the muffin recipe I made was to reduce the nutmeg to 1/2 teaspoon because I find nutmeg to be overpowering. For the last step, I melted butter and used a grill brush to brush it onto the muffins and then dropped them into a large ziploc bag with the 1/4 cup sugar and 1/2 tsp cinnamon mixture and shook to coat. It was easy and mess free that way. That amount of cinnamon sugar easily coated 2 batches so the original recipe amount is definitely overkill.

country:

text:
This is a delicious recipe but don't make the same mistake I did. After reading one review I decided I too wanted to use buttermilk and have them taste more like my home made donuts. So as suggested, I eliminated the baking powder and used baking soda. I could not get them out of the muffin tins! I threw the first batch away because all I had were crumbs left from digging them out of the pans. (yes, I did grease the pans!) I even tried some in a regular sized muffin tin, but had the same bad luck in getting them out. I tried loosening them  around the edges, I tried letting them cool. Nothing worked! Had I used papers I would not have had this problem, but I suspect the muffins would have stuck to them as well. So I began again and used baking powder. They came out much better. I made a double batch and make a small cake and 6 regular muffins. I was so frustrated by this point that I didn't take the extra step of dipping in butter and then sugar. I just sprinkled a mix of cinnamon and sugar over the tops. They are good and worth making, but if you mess them up like I did, beware!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/6111082.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
It is very true to it's name. In taste and texture it is like a donut, in the shape of a muffin. I only gave it 4 stars because I didn't make the recipe as written, I would've given 4 1/2 if I could. For one, I only have large muffin tins, which yielded me 6 delicious muffins, though not that large at all... Second, for the cinnamon-sugar topping, as some suggested, I only did the tops. After removing from the oven I lightly spread margarine on the tops of the muffins with a spatula, then lightly sprinkled sugar, then cinnamon on top. Any more than that would've been too much! Also I did cut the nutmeg to 1/2 tsp, was plenty for me, and I wouldn't dare cut it out entirely, that is what made the taste so donuty (sp?) All in all it was different, but altogether a good, interesting recipe. I wish I had the mini muffin tins!

Updated Review:  While my initial attempt at this recipe was nothing special, I decided to try again.  They were hugely popular this time.   The major change was less baking time.  Mini muffins in my pans are done in as little as 9 minutes depending on the recipe.  Also, I sift all dry ingredients now, and only use White Lily flour.  (*original review: 10/14* The taste was good, but the texture was off-putting for some reason, probably a mistake I made in preparation somehow.  One comment I got was "Is this cinnamon cornbread?"   I was so excited to make these because of all the positive reviews, so I am disappointed at my failure.   Perhaps I will try again to see if they turn out better next time.)

text:
I would have LOVED this and given it 5 stars except I found I had to modify it slightly. My first batch yielded about 20 very small (1-bite) donuts. I filled mini muffin tins half way as instructed, cooked for 17 min @ 375 but found them to be a bit too crunchy and way too small. In the next batch I added a 1/2 tsp salt to the batter and filled the mini muffin tins almost all the way. This yielded about 16 total muffins. I also baked them for 15 in stead of 17 min and they're amazing!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I just baked these using my donut pan and I'm really happy with how they turned out. I tried two other baked 'donut' recipes before and was very disappointed with the texture--like rubbery sponges. Not these. Their texture and taste is pretty close to a proper deep-fried donut minus the huge vat of oil. I'm not a big fan of nutmeg, so following another reviewers suggestion, I only used 1/4 tsp (pre-ground from a jar, not freshly grated) and I added 1/4 tsp of salt and 1/2 tsp of vanilla. The recipe only made 8 thin-ish donuts, so next time I'm going to double the recipe and add more batter to each well, to see if I can get them a bit plumper.

text:
I've made this over and over again. Everyone loves it! There is only one thing I do differently. At the end, instead of dipping the muffins in the butter and then rolling them in cinnamon sugar, I mix the butter and cinnamon sugar, dip them in that mixture, and then let it drip down the sides of the muffin. Either way, this is an amazing recipe. And I'm not kidding, I make these for birthdays a lot and EVERYONE love them!

Display Name:
Victoria Valdez Naranjo
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/2780001.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
These are just cute, like donut holes, and delicious! Definitely a 5 star-plus!  Quick and easy too. I made 22 mini donut holes. I don't care for nutmeg so I used cinnamon instead. Then when they were done, I let them cool for 3 minutes and then loosened them a bit with a knife but left them in the pan. I melted the butter, put it in a small tiny bowl and just dipped the top of the donut hole in, then immediately dipped it into the sugar/cinnamon mix and sprinkled some of the sugar around the rest of the donut hole - it stuck to the sides/bottom even without butter! I let them sit on a wire rack while the kids got dressed for school, then put them in mini ziplock bags for their morning snack.  They LOVED them and I loved having a couple with my coffee, too!  This weekend I may make more and dip them into melted chocolate and sprinkles....or glaze some too! Perfect for a healthy donut craving substitute. :)

I followed the recipe, but used less sugar in the batter and almond milk, hoping to make them a bit more nutritious!  I also would not use melted butter to top them when I make them again.  They are tasty enough that all they need is some cinnamon and sugar or splenda mix.  I got 22 mini muffins, but they did not puff up as so many said.

None
country:
None
text:
I made these with a regular-sized muffin pan and used butter instead of margarine, but kept the recipe and baking time the same otherwise. I only ended up with 8 regular-sized muffins. On its own, the muffin tastes rather bland, though I think the nutmeg is a nice touch--albeit not the first thing you think of when it comes to "donut". The finished muffin did come out nice, moist, and had a pleasant texture, so props for that. With the cinnamon-sugar topping, these turn out quite tasty, but if you coat anything like this in cinnamon and sugar, it's already going to taste much better. They're very simple and easy to make and overall, not bad.

text:
This is a wonderful recipe and these little gems are a great tiny bite to go along with a healthy breakfast!  I didn't change much, it is a perfect recipe as is, but I did use coconut oil instead of margarine and I don't believe it changed anything, however, I did add a pinch of salt to make up for the missing salt.  I also didn't use margarine for the dipping, I used butter, but only 2 tbsp and only dipped the top but I did roll the entire thing in sugar and it stuck fine with only the tops dipped.  There was still half of the butter still in the bowl, next time I will only melt 1 tbsp at a time.  I love the nutmeg flavor of these, they really do taste like little donuts. . .I wonder if powdered sugar would be good to dip into next time. . .Thanks Dianne, you made our scrambled egg breakfast much sunnier this morning!!

text:
Do I even have to say how amazing these muffins are? 4 stars simply b/c you MUST REDUCE THE NUTMEG! 3/4 tsp is OVERKILL. 1/4 tsp for 24 muffins is PLENTY. And also: make sure melted butter is piping hot so the cinnamon sugar adheres and does not get "chunky". One of the best recipes I've found- so simply, easy, & delicious!

text:
I met up with a friend and I told her that I was bringing a treat along. I decided to try this recipe and it was a HUGE hit. She loved them and my kids couldn't get enough of them. I doubled the recipe and used only 3/4 tsp of nutmeg (I thought 1 1/2 tsp would have been too much and over-powering). I baked them in the mini mini muffin tins and got 47 muffins (I did a little taste testing, otherwise, I would have had 48). I then dunked them into butter and then into cinnamon sugar (I used a lot more than what is called for in the recipe), and let me tell you ... these are the best donut muffins I have ever made! These were gone in day and my 5 year old asked me to make them again. This is now my go-to recipe for donut muffins. Thanks for sharing, Dianne!

text:
I made these for our school drama production "At The Circus Big Top".  They were a huge hit.  I made the muffins a couple of hours ahead of time and kept them warm in my crock pot.  In order to serve them to order like real mini donuts, I transferred the warm muffins to a large bowl, drizzled with butter and then tossed them in the cinnamon and sugar just like real mini donuts. I put them in paper lunch bags, so it was just like the real thing.  The kids loved them, and this was so much safer then deep frying.  I made 216 donuts and sold out! ( our school is only 24 kids!)

text:
These are awesome. I used 1/2 tsp nutmeg in the batter, and only used about 2 TBS margarine, 1/4 cup sugar, and 1/2 tsp cinnamon for the topping (I just rolled the tops in the margarine, then cinnamon sugar). My boys devoured these in no time flat! Will definitely make these again for a breakfast treat or weekend snack.

text:
These are awesome muffins. The nutmeg makes them. The only thing I did differently was to make full sized muffins and sprinkle the tops with cinnamon and sugar BEFORE baking. They don't need the extra grease and mess. I tried them as originally written first and they are good, but they really soak up the butter, and I found them much more greasy than I cared for. Still 5 stars for a fantastic taste.

So good!  I received a mini donut maker (Babycakes) for Christmas and have been looking for a good batter.  This is going to be my new go-to recipe!  Only change I made was to use 1/2 tsp nutmeg and 1 tsp cinnamon.  So light and fluffy!  Filled each cup about 2/3 full and waited for light to turn green.   Made about 15 donuts. text:
It was definitely easy to make and good. Mine were a little dry and that might have been because I brushed the top with butter, but did not dunk in the whole muffin in the butter as some reviewers said it made it soggy then and hard to keep in one piece. I left out the nutmeg and put in cinnamon because I did not have nutmeg. I used my 24 mini muffin pan and while I doubled the recipe, I only got 24 plus a bit more batter left for maybe 4 more which I did not make. I don't know why this happened. The size of my muffins looked like ones people posted, so not sure why I did not get 48. That is a huge difference and I double checked to make sure I did, in fact, double recipe and I did. 
I am not sure if I will make these again because as I said, they are kind of dry, but to be fair, I should make them again and roll the entire muffin in butter as it says.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
A-MA-ZING! I tried one of these hot out of the oven, and I was completely blown away. 

Made only two minor changes from the original recipe: added just 1/4 tsp of nutmeg and 1/4 tsp of cinnamon. I think it gave just the right amount of spice without being overpowering. And instead of dunking in the melted butter, I only dipped the tops in. Afterwards, though, I still rolled the entire muffin in the cinnamon/sugar. (This made for a better coating on top, but still some coating on the sides/bottom.)

What I love about these is they are crunchy on the outside, soft and chewy on the inside. In my book, that makes them better than donut holes! Caution: these are horribly addicting! If you're making them to serve more than two people, I would really consider doubling the batch. MOST DEFINITELY will make these again!

text:
These are just okay as written and the only thing that makes these edible is coating them in cinnamon/sugar.  However, the batter is ripe for improvements.  Next time, I may add more spice (maybe apple or pumpkin pie spice) to the batter and increase the sugar but use brown sugar instead or a combination of both.  Then I would create a spice glaze and swirl the glaze into the batter before baking and glaze them afterwards.  As written, the batter after baking is not very pleasant until rolled in sugar/cinnamon.  Plagiarized or not, the recipe needs vast improvement.  I would give it only 1 star but it is very easy with very few ingredients.

text:
I just added a few sprinkles of cloves and ginger to make it more like pumpkin pie. They were all gone in a half an hour among 5 girls. We really liked them. Just a note: if you don't have mini muffin tins, and you use regular size, they're going to be puffy disks, like the bottom of the muffin tin. If you cook them the recommended time, because disks are thinner, they'll be crispier on the bottom, which my friends didn't mind, but if you want lighter ones, just watch your timing. Although they look light and maybe still baking, they're probably already done. Thanks for the recipe! I don't care if it's in a cookbook that I'll never read somewhere. If you didn't post it, I wouldn't have it to share with my friends, so thank you very much.

I used butter instead of margarine, so maybe that's where things went wrong.  These were good, but not great--the base dough recipe is a little bland with the blandness covered up by slightly excessive nutmeg and cinnamon.  They are easy to make, but I don't think that I would make them again.

text:
Since I try to be a "healthier" cook, I used 1/4 cup sugar and 1/4 cup of Splenda for the batter part. It did not look like it would blend when you added the milk as it was very lumpy, but went ahead anyway. I used FF milk and 1/2 C. whole wheat and 1/2 cup all purpose flour. They cooked perfectly in my Wilton 24 mini muffin pan in exactly 10 minutes. I rolled half of the muffins and cinn/sugar mix and the other half in powdered sugar. My kids loved both versions and they had no idea they were "Healthier".

text:
These are delicious. Family gobbled them up. Made exactly 24how in my pampered chef mini muffin pan. Also some reviews say its too much nutmeg. I think it depends on the nutmeg quality. I had store brand nutmeg thats a few months old so I used the full amount. If I had fresh gourmet quality nutmeg I would cut it in half. I used whole wheat flour and real butter. The whole wheat added a nutty flavor but also made them crumbly. Love how easy they are. In one hour they were made, eaten, and the dishes washed! Thanks! I will make these again.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is the easiest thing to make. It's actually easier than making pancakes from scratch - and without the cholesterol from eggs - probably a little healthier. And it's so delicious! We don't have mini muffin tins so we used traditional muffins. 

We also used white wheat whole grain flour because it's the only thing we had on hand. Delicious and "heartier" than a donut. 

My husband and I both feel like it's wiser to treat this as a muffin because the consistency is muffin-like. But, as such, this opens a brand new world of possibilities. Adding brain and cinnamon apple chunks! Blueberries! Fiber powder mix!

This is our new breakfast food and it's something I intend to wow the in-laws with the next time they're in town.

I didn't make any modifications (except the type of flour used) - and this was amazing.

Used half whole wheat pastry and half all-purpose flour; 1/4 tsp nutmeg; reduced the topping sugar to 1/4 cup but left the cinnamon at 1 teaspoon and should have cut the topping margarine as well, as had about half left. (No one guessed about the substitution of ww flour!)

So here's the thing: I don't bake.  At the very most, I bake two times a year.  But this recipe made me want to bake these, because I love those cinnamon donuts and it makes me sad I can only get them at fairs.  So after months, I finally bucked up and did it.  And they are INCREDIBLE.  I don't know how, but they really do taste just like cinnamon donuts.  It's uncanny.  And they are so easy to make, it's ridiculous.  The only change I made was I had to use sour cream because I didn't have any milk.

text:
This is almost the same as a recipe I've been using for over 20yrs. The changes are...1/4 tsp nutmeg, use shortening instead of the butter or marg, in the batter(the batter stays whiter) and before you bake, drizzle the melted butter (use butter for this part) over top of each muffin and sprinkle with the cinnamon sugar mix, then bake.

text:
Sifting the flour and baking powder will lend a better texture as well as adding a pinch of salt and the grating (using a microplaner) of one lemon for its zest.  A more complex flavor can be had with some high qualiy vanilla and use half of the nutmeg.  Many kudos for a no egg recipe.  I liked the simple quickness of this recipe, but would choose to only sugar coat the tops  Sometimes less is more

Made exactly as written.  Child tested.  Child approved.  Son ate one and said to make another batch and to replace his daily after school and lunch chocolate chip cookies with these from now on. They are muffins, not cupcakes and a whisk or mixer would likely overwork the batter.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Ok, I love this recipe! I make it all the time but I always double it. I never dip in butter then cinnamon and sugar. I just add a crumb topping. This time I wanted to try something different so I didn't double the recipe. I messed up and added twice the butter and thought they were ruined but it made them lighter! I sprayed the mini muffin pan and then covered the bottoms of the cup in cinnamon and sugar, then put about half a tsp of batter in and covered the tops with cinnamon and sugar. They came out  great!! I don't know why anyone would dip them in butter, it is so much easier to just add the cinnamon and sugar before you bake them! With the crumb topping and made as small muffins, they are great too!

text:
These are just WONDERFUL.  Thumbs up from all my kids!  I was skeptical at first; wondering what made them taste "donut" but gosh darn the name is right!  These darling little muffins are so yummy and easy.  I followed some advice of others and didn't dip my muffin in melted butter.  I brushed the tops and sprinkled cinnamon sugar over them while they were hot and that was just enough taste.  They didn't rise at all and so I would definitely fill them more than 1/2 way.  I would definitely double if not triple the recipe as the first batch went so quick.  Also based on recommendations of other reviewers used 1/2 teaspoon of nutmeg which was just enough (I hate nutmeg anyhow).

text:
I found these to be a little on the dry side straight out the oven but became more moist after being packaged up for a day or so. Next time I will use oil instead of margarine or replace 1/2 of the milk called for with oil as my family enjoys moist baking. Flavour was perfect - exactly the donut hole flavour I was expecting! Since I was baking for spice enjoyers, I used a mix of 1/2 tsp nutmeg, 1/2 tsp cinnamon and a dash of ground cloves in place of the 3/4 tsp nutmeg called for in the batter for a nice spicey flavour. This worked well. Thank you for a great recipe!

text:
I followed the recipe (almost) exactly. I didn't have nutmeg so I substituted the pumpkin spice in the same amount. I also followed the baking times and they were a little well done after 15 minutes. We loved them. I love to bake but typically, the baked goods get sent to work, school or neighbors because we don't eat them that much. These stayed in my house and lasted 2 whole days before they told me to make some more. The first batch I used butter. The second batch, made today, I used margarine. No difference in flavor. I also cooked them for 12 minutes and they are perfect. Based on the butter/sugar/cinnamon add on at the end, I did cut it down so I wouldn't have as much left over. I quadrupled the batch I made today and only tripled the topping. It was perfect. I will be making these again and again. Loved them!

text:
OMG!!!!
What is wrong with me????  I made this recipe and cut the nutmeg back like everyone said and put a little cinnamon in the dough.  I used butter instead of margarine like someone suggested.  I was able to divide the dough between 24 mini muffins (Yay me!).  The dough tasted yummy by the way!  I baked for 10 minutes while I was sitting here reading other recipes, reviews, etc.  I was smelling this wonderful aroma and getting all cocky--I was thinking I should get on Amazon and order my son some mini muffin pans because he loves cinnamon sugared food and doesn't mind cooking.  Then the timer went off and I looked in the oven......
Some of my muffins looked kind of rugged and sort of raised and some were just totally over running the cups and flat flat flat!  I let them cook a few more minutes before taking them out of the oven.  Guess what!?  they were so stuck to the pans even though I had sprayed each cop with Pam.  24 mini muffins turned into 17 muffins.  I guess I ate the other 7 crumb by stuck crumb!  These are so good but I need to work at making mine look like the pictures.

I doubled the recipe and it made 12 regular size muffins. I tried dipping the muffin in the melted margarine as stated in the recipe, but it didn't seem to work too good for me. Instead, I used a pastry brush and brushed the muffins while they were still in the muffin pan. I then sprinkled the sugar and cinnamon mixture on top. I had some of the sugar mixture left over. Everyone in my family loves these.

text:
Because anything with flour usually needs some salt and these desperately need that at least.  I think they could be fluffier.  Perhaps using half brown sugar instead of straight sugar.  Its important to cook only until lightly golden brown, that is what makes them softer and moist.  Also fill the cups to the rim and they will puff up like a muffin, also pull down the temp to 350, baking for closer to the 15 minute side of the 20 minute top range.  20 is too long.  These probably wont taste like you think they will.

I just baked these an hour ago and they are very good! After reading some reviews, I added 1/2 tsp of nutmeg and 1/4 tsp of cinnamon to the batter instead of the 3/4 tsp of nutmeg it calls for. Make sure you add a generous amount of the coating because the muffin absorbs it pretty quickly. :)

text:
These are fantastic.  My husband got a sweet tooth at the end of a busy day, so I looked for a recipe that was quick, and didn't require any eggs (I ran out that day). And since I was qoing for simplicity, I baked this recipe in an 8x8 glass pan. FANTASTIC. After baking for about 20 minutes, I brushed the top (liberally) with melted I Can't Believe It Not Butter (it's pretty much all I use), then sprinkled with the sugar/cinnamon mix (you only need half of what's called for if you make them this way) very liberally.  We ate just about all of them.  I found the nutmeg to be a perfect contrast to the sugar and cinnamon. For a Thanksgiving twist, I'm considering making this with pumpking pie spice.  I'll check more reviews and see if anyone else has tried making them that way. All in all: THIS IS A FANTASTIC TREAT.When you're in a hurry or when you're not!
