text:
I made these donut muffins last night because I had about a half hour to spare and thought my daughter would like some home-made goodies to take to work for her break.  I thought I had nutmeg but I didn't so I used some pumpkin pie spice (less than a half teaspoon)and they turned out really good.  My daughter tried a couple when they were still warm and gave me her ok. I think it's because she loves anything that has sugar and cinnamon on it.  She can be pretty picky about things so her approval of these donut muffins meant they were ok to make again.  The recipe said to start off using a large bowl which I did but then I ended up doing a lot of scraping of the bowl to use up the last few little muffin tin spots.  Next time, Ii'll use a much smaller bowl.  These donut muffins do kind of taste like donut holes and they're a great snack to make when you don't have a lot of time to fuss with a recipe.

country:
None
text:
My family really enjoyed these. I think it's the coating that makes it so good. The bare muffin itself was just okay. They were easy to make and VEGAN! I reduced the nutmeg to 1/2 tsp as others suggested. I did not dip them in melted margarine (actually used Earth Balance) at first and the sugar/cinnamon adhered nicely. After about 16 muffins, they had cooled down to the point were I needed the melted margarine to get the sugar/cinnamon to stick. We liked the non-margarined version, so I will have to work faster next time. I used my OXO small cookie scoop/disher to portion the batter and got 24 mini muffins. They're very pretty too, so they'll add some sparkle to a holiday table.

Yummy!!  Hubby rated them a 4 of 5, which is pretty spectacular since he isn't a huge fan of nutmeg.  Instead of dipping them in butter, I simply put the warm muffins into a freezer bag with the suger/cinnamon mix and shook.  Dipping them in butter sounds wonderfully delicious, though.  I might have to try it that way the next time I make them.  Thanks for a delicous recipe!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Great recipe!  The first time I tried these I doubled the recipe but instead of doubling the overpowering nutmeg I used 3/4 t. nutmeg and 3/4 t. pie spice.  Also, I used 1/4 c. melted butter and 1/4 c. applesauce to reduce the fat but still have some rich flavor.  I omitted the butter in the topping and placed 1 tsp cinnamon and 1/2 c of sugar in a sandwich-sized zippered baggie and tossed 2-3 right out of the oven muffins and shook to coat.  Placed them on a cooling rack and zipped up the leftover sugar mixture for the next batch.  My kids and husband loved them!  A double batch yielded exactly 3 dozen muffins for me.  Thanks for sharing the recipe!

text:
Tasty!  A couple of quick things:  I don't have a mini muffin pan, so I used a regular one and made twelve of these.  They had to cook the full twenty minutes.  Also, I thought I'd make things easier on myself and use paper muffin liners--big mistake, the muffins stick to the liners like crazy!  So I wound up leaving the muffins in the liners and only putting the butter and cinnamon-sugar combo on the tops (a pastry brush came in handy for this).  The only other change I made was to reduce the nutmeg to 1/4 teaspoon, as a personal preference.  They were excellent, thanks!

region:

country:
None
text:
I'm not a big fan of cake donuts, but one of my co-workers loves them, so I made these as a surprise for her.  Turns out I really liked them, too!  By scraping the mixing bowl with a silicone spatula, I had just the right amount of batter for 24 mini muffins.  I wasn't sure if I was supposed to dip the whole muffin in the butter and cinnamon sugar or just the tops, so I started out doing the whole muffins.  When I realized I was swiftly running out of melted butter, I switched to dipping just the tops.  I'll definitely make these again, but I'll need to double the recipe because 24 wasn't enough once we realized how delicious they are!  Thanks for a great recipe, Dianne!

These are AMAZING!!! They taste just like a donut, but without the extreme guilt of eating a fried, sugar dough.  I used half whole wheat flour, but followed the directions otherwise.  I made them and they were gone within a half hour with me, hubby, BIL, and 2y/o DD. Oink, oink!  I want to try them again (maybe right now) with applesauce replacing the margarine completely and reducing the sugar slightly and adding a little vanilla.  For rounded muffin tops, bake 25-50 degrees hotter for the first 2 mins, then reduce to correct heat.  These will be made over and over in my house.

text:
I had heard so much about these on the Recipe Exchange that I had to make them this morning.  What a pleasant little surprise.  I used butter instead of margarine and skim milk.  For the topping I used only 2 T of butter melted and it worked perfectly on 24 mini muffins.  I dipped the top in the melted butter and then into the bowl with the sugar/cinnamon (also cut in 1/2).  Perfect amounts.  You have to work fast as the little buggers are hot right out of the mini muffin tin but they are worth the danger!!  Oh, I also used only a dash of nutmeg and added a dash of salt also to the batter.

text:
These mini muffins were delicious! I followed the recipe except for the nutmeg part, just because I didn't have any. I substituted it for 1/2 tsp of pumpkin pie spice. I sprayed the bottoms of the pan with Pam and once they were done, I inverted them onto a cooling rack and they popped out. I was able to make exactly 24 mini muffins baking for 14 minutes. I dipped the tops only in butter but rolled the entire muffin in the sugar/cinnamon mix. These were so fast and easy to make...and I only had to wash one mixing bowl! Will definitely make again!

userID:

Display Name:
Marina Moffat Kaup
isPro:

10

161
favoritesCount:
374
recipesCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/2758193.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
These are fabulous!  The texture is just perfect, light & moist.  I actually liked that they weren't heavy & cakey.  They tasted like a donut without the heavyness.  I doubled the batch and after reading the reviews decided to use just 1/2 tsp nutmeg total, which I thought was perfect.  Nutmeg is a potent spice and I think using the recommended amount would have been way too overpowering.  With this change they are definitely 5 star.  I let them cool for almost 15 minutes then put them in a ziploc with the melted butter then another ziploc with the cinnamon sugar.  My whole family loved them and they disappeared fast. I will definitely make them again!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/1040985.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
These are too good and easy to be true!  I'm known for creating kitchen disasters, but this one didn't fall victim to that!  The ingredients are simple/probably in your kitchen pantry already, the "one bowl" preparation is quite welcoming (unless you want to include the small bowl you'll use for melting the margarine used for dipping them in later), and they taste fantastic as a treat by itself or with a hot drink or milk.  I baked mine for 17 minutes and they were perfect.  I also reduced the sugar in the batter to about 1/3 cup total.  Remove them from the pan a couple of minutes later and begin the "dipping/rolling" process.  That is the only part that takes time, but the ease of the entire recipe makes this one final step very much worth it.  They're not exactly healthy treats, but they're also not as harmful to your health as a traditional donut hole that has been fried. :)  I plan to use whole wheat flour next time..  and maybe even add maple extract to the batter, or pure maple syrup to the margarine used for the dipping.  Thank you for sharing your recipe with us.

text:
Wow!  They do taste just like mini donuts.  I took others advice and cut back on the nutmeg just a bit.  I tripled the batch but only got 48 mini muffins, when after reading reviews I expected more.  I used my Tbsp to fill the cups, sprayed the pan with Pam and they popped right out.  Let them cool 10 mins and then put all 24 in a ziploc added butter and shook. (If I didn't let them cool long enough they broke apart a bit) Then 4-5 at a time into a paper lunch sack with the sugar mixture and shook.  Delicious. Just as good cold as they are warm.  Will definitely make again!  Super kid friendly recipe too!

text:
I made this for Recipe Group, my first one:)  I thought these were really nice, but not exactly what I was expecting.  I think in order to taste more like the doughnut holes they need to be "cakier" if that makes sense.  And I did make a second batch splitting the nutmeg in half and adding cinnamon for the other half, this was better for me and the hubs pallet.  So overall, I think this was a great idea and they taste nice, but the Nutmeg is a bit overpowering and the texture could be more dense.  Thanks Dianne for this quick yummy recipe!!! ATTN: UPDATE!! ok, if you don't like these right away you HAVE to try them again the next day.  the texture was better and the nutmeg wasn't as strong, i think because the flavors were able to "mingle".

text:
I made this as the Recipe Exchange group recipe for the week of May 24th. Wow, I was surprised how much I like these! I didn't expect to because I'm not really a fan of nutmeg, but I really like it in these muffins! The texture of this eggless muffin also surprised me; I didn't realize they'd still be tender without an egg, but they are. Not much else to say, except that I look forward to making these again sometime with white whole wheat, because I'm sure this recipe will hold up wonderfully! Note: This recipe made 12 mini-muffins and 5 muffin-tops for me, made as written with no changes (well, butter instead of margarine). Thanks for the recipe!

text:
After reading some suggestions from other reviewers I replaced the milk in this recipe with buttermilk. The result: nutmeg muffins with a sour tinge to them. I've used buttermilk in other recipes and never had negative results, but I really think it ruined these. They're edible (what isn't, dipped in butter and rolled in cinna-sugar?) but I can't help wishing they were better. Thank goodness they were quick to make! I am giving this four stars, as benefit of the doubt, they're probably awesome and some bites are almost tasty. Made with buttermilk I'd give it two stars. I will probably try making these again someday (right now I have 24 sour ones to eat), but next time I will STICK TO THE RECIPE!

The first time I made these I did the recipe as calls.  It was way to much nutmeg.  (btw, nutmeg can make you sick) And I got a headache after eating them. And the nutmeg was overpowering  This time around I reduced the nutmeg to 1/4 teaspoon and added 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon and 1/4 teaspoon vanilla extract to the recipe.   Also, I cooked them only 15 mins.  THEY WERE DELICIOUS!  My husband loved them... and so did my kids. Will make again

I did make 2 changes by necessity. I had to use a full-size muffin pan. It made 6 large muffins. I had self-rising flour so I used 1 cup with no additional baking powder because the flour already had it. They turned out perfect at 25 mins on the second to the top rack. The outer edges were crispy and the inside was soft. I will make this again.

These are yummy & super easy!  I used butter, as opposed to margarine.  I also decided to coat the whole mini muffin in the cinnamon/sugar mixture.  My main (minor) change that I highly recommend:  When it came to the cinnamon-sugar that the donut muffin is dipped in, I used bakers, sugar, which is extremely fine, almost like a powder.  It made a HUGE difference!  Crave-able!  In fact, I think Iâ€™ll go make some right now!

text:
These were great! I was leery of the nutmeg, so I split the batter into three parts: plain, nutmeg, and blueberry. They were all wonderful! I was pleasantly surprised the nutmeg was not overpowering, only gave a nice warmth to the muffins. I got 22 muffins using a Wilton standard mini-muffin pan...My husband and I ate all but 10 of them! This is definitely a recipe I will keep and use again. Would be great for brunch or to give as a gift.

This recipe is DE-LISH!  I substituted ingredients, to use up what I had in stock:  quinoa and whole wheat  flour instead of all purpose flour,  1/2 cup plain, full fat, greek yogurt instead of milk,  1/4 c. stevia and 1/4 cup brown sugar instead of 1/2 c. of sugar and about 1 tsp of water and one egg. The cin-sugar topping isn't necessary, they're great as is.   I also used a regular muffin tin, and baked in a toaster oven.  Taste is unreal!

text:
Great recipe!  I decided to treat them like cinnamon sugar donut holes so I used 3/4 stick of melted butter and rolled the entire muffin in it. Then I placed twice as much of the cinnamon sugar mixture in a paper bag. After rolling the muffins in the butter, I placed them in the bag and shook cinnamon sugar in them. In addition, I made a powdered sugar glaze for dipping. Just a few more calories, but it was quite the decadent treat.

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/4569544.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this recipe as is with the only substitution of butter for the margarine. The yield was 24 mini muffins. Now, as Naples34102 mentions, it is correct "mini muffin tins" vary in size. I have two of these tins and I can see the difference in size by brand. Still, the recipe yielded a solid 24 mini goodies despite the size difference. Fill the tins halfway up. A tiny bit more will make them into little mushroom looking pieces of heaven. Cute too by the way! I do however think that the discrepancy in size did not help when I had to dip them in the spiced sugar. I had to add a bit more because it was not enough for my batch. Maybe it has to do with the amount of butter that each little muffin absorbs. The more butter the more sugared spice will stick to the muffin. Watch for that! Other than that, I am very happy with the recipe. Will make it again. It is very good to bring to a small gathering. I will also try other toppings. It suits itself to so many kinds of simple toppings.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
These came out really good!  They really do taste like donuts.  

A few comments / changes for next time...

1) I only had a regular muffin tin.  There is enough batter to fill each of the 12 cups a little less than half way.  It actually produces a good "crust" to soft inside ratio.

2) Next time, I'll double recipe because the 12 muffins went really fast.

3) The sugar / nutmeg ratio is good.  If you don't like nutmeg, you could probably reduce it a bit.

4) I had a fair amount of leftover cinnamon/sugar after rolling the butter coated muffins.   I'll reduce the amount by about a third next time.

text:
These are very good but sweet, which I guess they're supposed to be! I didn't want a strong nutmeg flavor, so I only used 1/4 tsp and it was fine. They were getting too brown too soon, so another time I may try lowering the oven temp to 350. Someone mentioned not dipping in butter, just putting them in a paper bag with the sugar-cinnamon mixture. That would probably work, too.  I also like the idea that someone suggested about using pumpkin pie spice. That would be a good sub for the fall, either in the mixture or adding to the sugar dusting at the end. I'm placing a few of these in cellophane bags tied with ribbons to bring to a Kielbasa Fest at my church. Thanks for the recipe!

text:
Wow these are unpleasant. I was looking for a morning no-egg recipe as I have ran out. I tend to prefer recipies that treat sugar as a functional ingredient rather than a main one. I have trained myself to weed out recipies where the sugar to flour ratio is greater than 1:4. I was in a hurry today and didnâ€™t check. This recipient features sugar very prominently and if you do not like overly sweet baked goods ( like  me) you will hate this one.

I couldnâ€™t even bring myself to add the topping as I could not imagine adding any more sugar to these. There is so much there already the crust is... well, very crusty.

These will get dumped unfortunately- I will keep looking  and stick to my go to muffin recipe for now.

text:
Like another reviewer I made these as regular sized muffins and just brushed the tops with butter and sprinkled the cinnamon sugar very generously.  These are amazing. Definitely satisfied my donut cravings.  I used fresh nutmeg and just eyeballed a good amount.  Still could taste the nutmeg without it being overpowering.  I would not leave out the nutmeg.  It definitely is a secret ingredient that sets these apart from just a cinnamon sugar type dessert.  This is a great recipe too for people following a vegan diet.  I didn't miss the egg at all.

text:
My daughter requested mini donut muffins for her birthday treat at school. This was a dry run to make sure we liked the recipe, and thank goodness I didn't just make them and send them, because they were awful. all you can taste, even with all the cinnamon and sugar, is the nutmeg. It was so strong it made us physically sick. I retraced my steps thinking I must have made a mistake and put in too much nutmeg and I didn't. I guess nutmeg is probably just not for me, and if you like these that's wonderful! I just wanted to serve a warning to anyone who doesn't care for strong spice taste - especially nutmeg.

These are DANGEROUSLY good! Warning: This recipe will make it very easy to over indulge. I used butter instead of margarine. Threw in a tiny bit of cinnamon into the batter (although, not needed.) FYI- They will soak up the melted butter at the end, if you leave them in longer before dipping in the cinnamon-sugar topping. However, the soaked butter ones probably tasted the best so make sure you have a little extra butter in the fridge, just in case. This recipe made 20 mini muffins...

text:
A keeper recipe ! Easy and irresistible by all . Adjust the amount of sugar coating to your liking. I dunked the entire mini muffin in the butter, drain slightly and then rolled into the sugar,this provided a nice 'crusty' sugary coating once cooled off.  For some I dipped just the top  and only sugared the top portion.  Both equally nice!!

I made these, and the only change I did was I used unsalted butter instead of margarine.  I used the full 20 minutes of baking time because I was concerned about them being undercooked. userID:
2435161
Display Name:
I love baking!
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
13
favoritesCount:
48
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614262.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was a great little homeade breakfast snack that was just as easy to make as pancakes.  I like that the recipe is simple and is only for about 12-16 mini muffins. I used butter as per the cooks note & did not change any of the recipe except for on the mixing technique. In order not to over stir the batter:  I sifted all the dry ingredients together in one bowl (dry team), and in a seperate bowl I throughly mixed only the wet ingredients together (wet team). Then when I was ready, I combined and folded them together with as little stirring as possible, and put them right into the oven.  A toothpick was clean in about 10-15 minutes. Used 2 pie pans for the melted butter & sugar cinnamon mix afterwards. Perfect, easy, and husband loved it. Can serve hot but I thought room temperature was better. I think it could probably could even be made a day in advance. Could make a yummy dessert and even go with ice cream!!  Very nice recipe! Thanks for sharing!

userID:
6368436
Display Name:
Demo
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674168.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Perhaps using butter changes the baking time?  Or perhaps it was the dark muffin tins I used.  I doubled the recipe and found that the first batch...baked for 15 minutes...was much too long.  They were hard on the bottom.  I baked the 2nd batch for only 13 minutes and they were amazing.  I also found that the amount of butter suggested was nowhere near enough for dipping prior to sugaring these.  I had already doubled the recipe.  I melted another half a stick, 2 tablespoons at a time, because I kept running out.  I don't know if the problem was that I used butter rather than margarine, which I understand was the original ingredient suggested in the recipe, or that my butter wasn't sufficiently liquid.  I made a mess in my microwave trying to heat the butter to the right consistency, as it kept exploding.  I also appreciate it when ingredients say, "divided" when they are used in 2 or more parts of a recipe.  I didn't dump without reading this time, but I have in the past.  The 2nd batch I made was great and I may try these again. Hopefully I'll remember to subtract a few minutes of baking time the next time!

country:

text:
Reviewed 4/9/17.
Amazing sweet mouthfuls of deliciousness!!
The DH and I could not stop devouring these this morning. I followed the recipe exactly except substituted butter for the margarine. Half of the muffins were dipped in the butter before rolling in cinnamon sugar and while these were sinfully awesome, the amount of cinnamon sugar clinging to the muffins was a bit much for our tastes. The second half of the muffins were not dipped in butter, but were rolled in the cinnamon sugar mixture while still warm and turned out absolutely perfect!  The lovely flavor of the muffins wasn't overpowered by the quantity of the sugar this way.  We LOVE the contrast of the earthy nutmeg flavor in the muffin with the spicy cinnamon in the sugar, it is so yummy and warm in a back home in Mom's kitchen sort of way.  The muffins were light and had excellent crumb.  These won't turn out dry if you determine your baking time by the look of the muffin, not by a time given in this recipe or another post - as mentioned before, there are a myriad of sizes of muffin pans. My mini muffin pan creates muffins a little larger in diameter than a quarter and I started watching mine at about 7-8 minutes.  I think you could use this recipe as a base and it would also be excellent with variations like eliminating the nutmeg and adding vanilla, almond, lemon or other extracts and changing up the coatings like subbing the cinnamon for cocoa,  pumpkin pie or apple pie spice, lemon-flavored sugar, adding lave

text:
This is an excellent muffin recipe with a tender crumb.  I didn't have milk, so I used almond coconut milk out of necessity.  I wanted to make them less messy for the grandkids, so I just sprinkled a teaspoon of cinnamon sugar on top of each of the six extra large muffins before baking.  I was afraid that they might not be sweet enough, but they were.   Grandsons devoured them, even though they thought the nutmeg was a bit strong.  But that fades nicely as they set awhile, and to my liking, I would not reduce it.  Thank you!

These are very tasty! I had trouble the first time baked because I over baked them. One thing to know in advance is that they don't brown like other baked goods. Nutmeg was too much for my taste. I don't like nutmeg so tried without it and added cinnamon the second time. Was good but might try a pinch of the nutmeg with the cinnamon next time. It seemed like a lot to dip in butter after baking so just popped out of pan and rolled in sugar and some in powdered sugar. My boys really enjoyed both ways. These are good and tasty, just need to work on baking time.

Delicious!  Everyone in the family lives them and it's hard to eat just one! They were good except the nutmeg gave off a funny taste.  Next time I will try either just vanilla or mix in some more lemon juide to give it a better taste.  Tip:  If you use  the 24 min cupcake papers, definitely spray the inside of the papers!.  I didn't and they stuck to the bottom.  But it was easy and the grandkids loved to make them and sprinkle the sugar on them.

text:
Based on another reviewer's suggestion, I immediately doubled the recipe, which gave me exactly 36 mini muffins.  I did fill the cups about half-way, and they more than doubled in size.  The batter took less than 5 minutes to throw together, which was fabulous.  I set a timer to check on them in 15 mins but they were quite over-done by that time.  I'd suggest setting a timer for 10 mins and  watching them closely thereafter.  Despite being crispy on the bottom, these were very tasty, especially after the addition of the cinnamon sugar.  Great recipe!

I did not like the taste of the nutmeg in the muffin. Also I ran out of the melted butter when rolling them to coat and then in the cinnamon sugar, so I just rolled them in the cinnamon sugar while still warm and it was just fine. So the next time I make them I won't roll them in melted butter. It will keep the calorie  count down. I didn't have a mini muffin pan, but I did have a pan that makes cake pops. The pan made the muffins round and they were very CUTE. The amount of the batter was perfect for amount of this cake pan size of 18.  I definitely will make them again.

These don't taste just like donut holes, but they are tasty. If you want a less sweet and healthier option don't roll them in butter after baking but go straight to the cinnamon sugar, you MUST do it while they are hot or the cinnamon sugar won't stick. 
I added some vanilla extract to mine. I also think that one could use powder sugar instead of cinnamon sugar at the end, that dip the tops into melted chocolate.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674158.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a five star recipe for what it is - an easy, no-fry (therefore somewhat healthier) version of a donut hole. These are a weekly tradition at our Sunday brunch table. I do only one thing differently, and that is to cut back on the nutmeg. I use freshly ground nutmeg, and a little goes a very long way. I use perhaps 1/4 of a teaspoon and it seems absolutely perfect for us. You can't really go wrong with this one. Just tweak the spices (add some you love, leave out those you don't, adjust the amounts and types called for, whatever), or the topping. We love cinnamon sugar on ours, but my sister loves to make a thin icing to create a glaze. Yummy either way!!

text:
These were really good! My only problem was the baking time was too long. I baked them for 15 minutes, and the bottoms of the muffins were very dark brown. Any longer and they would have been burnt. Next time I'll take them out a few minutes earlier. I was skeptical about the "donut" flavor, but was pleasantly surprised! They even smelled like donuts while baking in the oven! My family loved them. My one complaint is that 24 doesn't go very far divided between my family of 6, so next time I'll have to double the recipe to prevent a riot!

Ok so these are pretty good i doubled the recipe to make 12 regular sized muffins as i don't have a mini muffin pan. I did not double the nutmeg tho and i am glad,  they were very strong at first but did mello out the next day! This is a very easy to make muffin i made them with my 3 and 4yrs old boys.  The batter was a little crazy at first when we added the milk it made the butter mixture clumpy but it did end up ok! I do think these would be better as mini muffins but that is no reflection on the recipe!  I think i will try them again as mini muffins and maybe swap out some of the white sugar for brown and review again!

text:
I have made this twice this week it was so good!  I made these exactly as written the first time.  They were so well received that I was asked to make them again- what better to make on a day with 24+ inches of snow?  This time I made the recipe as written and did two more batches - one with powdered sugar that I did not dip in the butter.  Second was rolled in white sugar that I had sitting with vanilla beans in to flavor it.  I also used a pastry bag with a large piping tip to inject some strawberry jelly into some of the muffins.  So good!  Next- will try Boston Cream and other variations.   Nice recipe to have younger kids help with, too.

text:
I just got a mini-muffin pan and tried these.  They are good.  A few comments.  They barely made 22 muffins and I sort of scrimped on filling them.  I would double the recipe next time.  I also will cook on 350 as the bottoms were too brown.  A little dry so I'll add more milk or maybe an egg.  I think I will cut back on the nutmeg by 1/4 and supplement with cinnamon.  I only used about half of the cinnamon coating but had separated it so I can use with the next batch. I'd also like to make these as regular size muffins.  It seems like a lot of changes but I like to write these notes for others and so I will remember them.  I will definitely make again!  Thank you.
Review:
Rating:
5

text:
These are very good, but don't do what I did!  I rolled them in the cinnamon/sugar mixture and thought more has to be better so I scooped up more of the cinn/sug mix and patted it on them after rolling them.  Not a good idea!  Turned out too sweet and too cinnamony(is that a word?).  So make them just the way the recipe says and there will be plenty of cinnamon/sugar on them when you roll them.

I wouldn't do it again for a class as mini muffins. They tasted good though and didn't last long.

text:
I really liked the taste of these, but didn't give it the 5 stars because they were a bit dry.  They were good enough that I want to make them again, and I think I'll try adding a bit more milk to moisten them.  I did get 24 mini-muffins out of the batter.  I would try minimally reducing the nutmeg next time, as it did give it that "donut" flavor, but was edging on a stronger "eggnog" flavor by being a wee bit too much.  Funny thing is I completely missed step 4 with the sugar coating.  Bummer!  I will try a reduced version of that next time, as I thought they were pretty tasty without and might just do with a sprinkle of brown sugar on top before putting into the oven.

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/1411637.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I was looking for a non-fruit muffin recipe for my kiddos and came across these.  We decided to try them, making just as directed (for me they made 16 mini muffins).  Here are my thoughts...  They take just like donuts, but without the frying.  Yumm!  I did think the nutmeg was a little on the strong side for my taste (not bad...we still ate them all fairly quickly ;), but next time I may try 1/2 tsp just to see the difference.  The only other thing I noticed was that there was barely enough butter to roll them in before dipping in the sugar/cinnamon.  So, maybe dip very lightly, or make sure you have extra butter just in case. 

All in all, when we're looking for a special treat, we'll definitely make these again!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made these for a Sunday brunch and they were a hit! I followed the recipe exactly for the first batch. AWESOME! For the second batch I added lemon extract and some grated lemon to the batter and frosted them with a lemon glaze. AWESOME again! Any flavor, really, would be yummy. I filled the tins about 3/4 full and was rewarded by 21 mini-muffins. I found the baking time to be spot-on so be careful not to overcook as I did in a subsequent batch. They are rather hard and dry if you do; not nearly as good as if you do it correctly. Also, I had to use half & half in one batch because I was out of milk. I noticed no difference in the outcome or taste. This will be a standby quick treat for unexpected guests & relaxing breakfasts.

country:
None
text:
Where have these been all my life??!  Wow, these were delicious.  I found that they came out of the pan the easiest if I did it right out of the oven and didn't overfill the tins. But I found they dipped in the butter and sugar the best, if they cooled a bit and solidified.  Otherwise, some crumbled and broke and made a mess.  I quadrupled the recipe as I was baking for my daughter's school blood drive.  It made a little over 3 pans of 24.  Also, I cut back the nutmeg to 1/2 tsp per batch, so 2 tsp total and it was perfection.  PERFECTION!

Made this exactly as written.  My pans are the mini "WearEver" brand.  I used my smallest scoop (maybe 1 tsp size?) and it made exactly 24.  Baked for only 10 min. and they were done. The pans are dark, so that's probably why they baked a little faster. Used margarine - next time I will use butter.  I just like the taste better.  My husband thought there was too much sugar on the outside - I thought they were perfect.  When it comes to sugared donut holes, I like them to have that crunch on the outside.  I just kept popping one in my mouth here and there as I cleaned up the kitchen.  I finally stopped after 8.........even then I wanted just 1 (or 2)more.   : )

These were just ok. I was excited about them because I thought they'd taste like donut holes, but alas...they did not. I made them with all 3/4 tsp nutmeg the first time and found the flavor to be too much. I guess I really don't like nutmeg and my family didn't care for them either. Still not great, but better. Texture was perfect and we liked the cinnamon-sugar topping, but the rest is so-so. I probably won't be making these again.

text:
Quick and easy recipe for something sweet & different. I bought a standard pan from Walmart for mini-muffins & ended up with enough batter for 30 mini-muffins. These were really good the night I made them while still warm. I would not advise making them for the next day as they hardened considerably overnight. My only complaint would be to cut down just slightly on the nutmeg (1/2 teaspoon instead), as it overpowered the topping in my opinion. I'll be making these again soon!

text:
Made a double batch of these last night, and I'm making another batch tonight. These were really good! The batter comes together quickly, and they bake up fast. I didn't get 24 from my batter- I got 17 on the first batch and 14 on the second (but my 8 y/o filled the pan on the second batch and overfilled them) I think the cinnamon sugar coating was a bit much at first-it was like getting a mouthful of sugar. But I put all the finished muffins in a large ziploc bag and took them on a picnic, and all the excess sugar fell off and they were perfect. Very cute, very yummy little muffins!

text:
Perfect!! I made these not even 15 min ago and all 24 are already gone! I few things I did differently: I added just a hint of cinnamon to the batter (nothing more than 1/8th tsp) and added a bit more milk because the batter seemed a bit dry for muffins. Be careful not to ever over mix muffin batter, as that'll give the gluten more time to form in the flour, making your muffins tougher. Defiantly going to make again, and they're perfect with an ice cold glass of milk!!

Shoebox
isPro:

recipesCount:

reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614247.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I absolutely love these little suckers and I can never eat just one. I've used this recipe many times now and I always end up doubling the recipe to have enough. I don't think the nutmeg is overpowering, but I'm rather fond of the taste to begin with. When I dip them in the margarine I usually find that I need about 1/2 a cup instead of only 1/4. Also, as I am not in possession of a mini-muffin tin currently, I found that I can just as easily use a regular muffin tin and only put enough dough in each divot to cover the bottom. You'll have little muffins (if a bit wide) that won't be under cooked in the middle and are still bite size!

userID:
5099179
Display Name:
ConnieLC
isPro:
False
followersCount:
1
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
16
favoritesCount:
82
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/1305944.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Just made these for the first time and they were really good. Unlike some other reviewers, I thought the nutmeg was just right. The potency of spices can vary a lot, though, based on their age and even the brand. I was doing a test run of these for an upcoming bake sale and I'm going to experiment with the next batch. Mine browned a little too much on the bottoms before getting golden on the top. The muffins seemed pretty wet after dipping them into the butter and the cinnamon sugar coating started lumping up after rolling the first few. I'm going to try reducing the heat to 350 since I'm using dark pans. I'll turn the baked muffins onto a baking pan, spray them with melted butter, toss and spray again. Then I'll put them on a rack, sift the cinnamon/sugar over them, toss and repeat.

They're soft, moist, and have just the right amount of nutmeg to be irresistible smelling. My sisters agreed with me that coating the entire muffin would be a bit much, so we only put the cinnamon sugar on the tops. These are definitely being mad again and SOON! Xxx

country:
None
text:
Followed the recipe as written except used butter and 1/2 tsp allspice in place of nutmeg (had none). Baked 24 little beauties perfectly! Instead of dipping in melted butter I placed the muffins in a large bowl and "stirred in" the butter using a silicone brush, making sure the muffins were lightly coated. Next I tossed in the cinnamon sugar mixture and removed the coated muffins to a serving plate with a slotted spoon.  In the end I used a lot less butter and achieved the same result.  Thanks for a great recipe, definitely a keeper!

text:
EXCELLENT!!! Will definitely make these many times over.  I followed the recipe exactly and was thrilled with the results.  My kids and I ate all of them up in one sitting, and the boys were asking for more.  The perfect hint of nutmeg with a soft inside and crunchy outside.  The only changes I would make next time is needing more margarine melted for dipping.  I did realize though, for those who want it a tad bit healthier (ha!), is that you really don't need margarine to dip it in.  The sugar mixture will stick to warm donuts without it.

text:
Very yummy! I wanted something to bring in the car for a weekend trip, and these seemed like a good idea. I used a Pampered Chef mini muffin tin and got exactly 24. I love the nutmeg, and I also like that there isn't egg in it. The only change I made was that I didn't want these *so* dripping in butter, so I just dunked the top in butter. Then I put them on my cooling rack and sprinkled them with cinnamon sugar - less waste and less mess on my fingers!

text:
Despite it being a Colorado Cache Recipe (and that's ok honey, because it's a goody), I just love these donuts. I remember one night, I was getting the batter ready for baking the next morning and I was completely out of nutmeg! *Gasp!* (and gasp you should). So in a pinch, I substituted Pumpkin Pie spice and everyone just fell head over heels for them. So now I make them at least once a month and I substitute different spices for the nutmeg. A time before that I did a sun-dried tomato herb I had and instead of the butter and cinnamon sugar glaze, I did a sour cream and chive spread.

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/1550421.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
First off, I am no muffin maker, so I had my doubts that I could even pull off this five star recipe. Saw this recipe on a number of food blogs but some had a long list of ingredients and that in itself was intimidating. Was out of nutmeg so I subbed a half teaspoon of apple pie spice and a quarter teaspoon of cinnamon for my spices and did add a half teaspoon of vanilla to the batter. Sprayed my pans with Pam and baked for fifteen minutes - had twenty four mini muffins that popped right out after three minutes cooling.They do have a donut texture, amazing. I think I could have pulled them out at a little less time but that's just my oven. I can see where some thought the taste was very mild, it's all in the texture and the toppings. I think an icing and sprinkles would really make them special. What a great, simple recipe with which to add your own touch, thanks Dianne!

text:
First off let me say that I am not a fan of nutmeg, therefore I didn't have any and made this with cinnamon to replace it.  I used real butter. I thought with the ease of this recipe it would be over the top, but I found it, just  o.k.  I would and intend to make this again when I do have nutmeg and will re-evaluate.  With just the cinnamon it did seem to be missing something.  Also I dipped the whole muffin in butter then in the sugar and cinnamon mixture and it was a little bit overwhelming with the butter flavor.  Next time I will just do the tops and see how that turns out.  Thanks for the recipe!!

I am giving these 3 starts because even though the taste is really good once you reduce the amount of nutmeg by half (otherwise it overpowers the batter), the recipe does NOT yield 24 mini muffins as the ones pictured. In order to get 24 as puffy as those, you probably need to 1 1/2 the recipe, if not double. We do not use white sugar or white flour at home, so I used whole wheat flour (King Arthur's) and Sucanat. The kids loved them, and so did we.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
GREAT recipe! First time, I followed the recipe exactly even though I don't care for nutmeg. Another reviewer didn't either, but loved the muffins. Nope, I still don't like nutmeg, so the next batch got a little cinnamon, allspice, and ginger. Perfect! Also, we wanted to eat them as warm as possible, so I brushed the tops with the butter while still in the pans and then generously sprinkled the tops with the sugar-cinnamon mixture. That worked great and was much less messy than the rolling approach. My mini muffin pan makes 24 muffins and the batter filled them all with none left over. Baking only took about 12 minutes, but my oven tends to be slightly hot even with a temperature gauge inside. Will definitely be making these again! Thanks for the recipe!!

text:
What?  Of course I'm not going to eat all of these addictive delicious little gems by myself! *crams one more into mouth while you're not looking*

This recipe is fabulous, Diane.  Thanks!  But because all cooks have to have the last, narcissistic word on any recipe, I will offer that a pinch of salt added to the sugar (I used superfine) in the topping is a nice offset.

I made two batches, one with all-purpose flour and one with high-gluten bread flour. Can't decide which I like best, but the texture and chewiness of the bread flour batch gained more raves from family.  For each batch I used a 1:1 combo of coconut oil and melted butter (both in the dough and for the topping).  The nutmeg is subtle, but genius in this recipe.

0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/483086.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
These muffins are divine. I am Canadian, and live very close to the Arctic circle where there are no donut shops (Tim Hortons for all those other Canadians out there!) and miss getting a tasty treat now and then. These are such a good replacement! I stuck to the recipe, used butter instead of margarine and used vanilla-flavoured soy milk.  Instead of dipping the muffins in the melted butter, I used a pastry brush so that the muffins wouldn't be to saturated. I gave them each a quick brush on the top and bottom and rolled them in the sugar and cinnamon. I doubled the batter but not the sugar and cinnmaon and I had plenty. Simply delicious!!!

text:
OMG! These are delicious! Just like little donut holes but not as bad because they're baked, not fried! I found that using a basting brush and brushing the melted butter on top of the muffins before they came out of the pan helped a lot. Then I popped them all out into a gallon zip top bag and shook. I ate about 5 and sent the rest with my husband to work or I would have finished them off. I think one of my favorite things about this recipe is how easy and quick they are to make!

text:
The second batch is in the oven...that should tell you how yummy these are!  I agree with everyone else, cut the nutmeg to 1/2 tea and add cinnamon and vanilla.  Making them into mini muffins is part of the charm of these!  When out of the oven I tossed in big ziplock with spiced sugar (cinnamon, vanilla, nutmeg, ect (from The Spice House)), shook them a bit and put them on a rack to cool.  Also topped some with glaze of powdered sugar, cinnamon and a few drops of milk.  Both are yummy, thus the reason for the 2nd batch!

These are good.  I think coating them in butter and the sugar mixture was a bit much for my taste.  Next time I will probably just dip the tops and see how I like that. I really want to taste the muffin rather than the coating.  I will try these again.

Updated 10/23/10 - everyone in the house tried these.  The grown ups liked them, the kids did not.  The flavor is lovely but coating them entirely in butter/sugar/cinnamon is overkill.  Next time I will only dip the tops and let the nutmeg flavor be the star.  Nice recipe

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Great recipe! Quick and easy to make and the flavor is fantastic. These smell so amazing I almost couldn't wait for them to cool to try one. I did make a few modifications to make the recipe more healthy though:  Substitute all whole-wheat flour for all purpose flour. Substitute sugar free applesauce for margarine in muffins, reduce white sugar in muffins to 1/3 cup. Brush with olive oil instead of margarine and reduce sugar topping to 1/8 cup (and you probably won't even use that much - I didn't!)

text:
Muffin pan sizes seem to vary quite a bit... I consider my pan I use often to be regular-sized but since I used muffin cups (makes clean up a breeze) the size says "jumbo". So I got four good-sized muffins. I used nutmeg to "taste" (rather, whether the fragrance seemed to be satisfactory in the batter) and added a tablespoon of cocoa powder for a light chocolate taste. I think these would taste fine without the dipping and rolling in sugar... The doughnut flavour isn't very pronounced, but it's there. These were simple to put together, but nothing out of the ordinary. It's really just your average muffin. I would make it again though if I needed a sweet treat in a pinch.

text:
These really did taste DELICIOUS! Even my boyfriend who isn't a big baked goods fan liked them and the first thing he said was " they taste like those cinnamon donuts!"  The only thing I changed is I cut back on the nutmeg, after reading other reviews, and I added a touch of cinnamon to the batter.   In hindsight, I really should have doubled the batter. I read reviews saying so, but I decided to just try it. I don't have mini muffin tins so I used my regular ones, and only filled them 1/3 of the way. It is just not enough of these tasty morsels! Next time I will be doubling and making them full sized ;-)  Oh ALSO, I found the easiest way for me to get them coated was to brush a little melted butter right on top while they were still in the pan, then pull them out, pop them in a ziploc bag and give them a toss in the cinnamon/sugar. They came out beautifully coated!

text:
Wow!  Mini muffins, big taste, very addictive! The first batch of these I screwed up and even as "rejects"  my kids were eating these as fast as I could dip them.  My second batch (in the picture) turned out perfectly.  These literally took a whole five minutes to throw together and it took 15 minutes in my oven.  I followed the directions and used the Wilton Silicone Mini Muffin Pans filled 3/4 full and got 16 perfect muffins.  I only dipped the tops in real butter and put them in a bag filled with the cinnamon sugar mix and this worked great.  Just for the record, I am not a huge nutmeg fan but loved it in these muffins.  Thanks for sharing, Dianne!!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
These are fantastic!  I've made them both as normal sized muffins (makes 6), as bigger mini muffins (12) and as little mini muffins (24) and they're all great.  I only use 1/2 t nutmeg because I'm not a big fan of it in excess.  That amount works well for this recipe though.  The muffins are great warm, room temperature, and even the next day if they make it that long.  These muffins are so easy to make and are an extra special treat I like to surprise my husband with some mornings :)  The only thing I'd like to note is that I've found 10 minutes to be spot on if you make 24 mini muffins (like what the recipe submitter says to do in her review) and 15-20 minutes will probably give you burned muffins, so keep an eye on them.

text:
Really good. This recipe makes 24 mini muffins, not 12 (Pampered Chef pan and small Pampered Chef scoop).  You only need to bake for 12 minutes.   I used 1/2 cup butter to roll them in.  Let them cool really well.  Then roll in butter, put in a paper bag with sugar/cinnamon mix and lightly toss-the butter absorbs into the paper bag so they're not too greasy.

city:

country:
None
text:
THE BEST! A+!!!! Loved this recipe. Simple, fool-proof and takes literally no time! I ate, and ate, and ate these all day yesterday. Gone in a few minutes. They taste great right out of the oven. Put the sugar (and cinnamon if you wish) in a brown bag and put the hot donut muffins in the bag, give it a shake- dump them into a plate and they will be gone in seconds. So yummy and tender. My recommendation: Add more nutmeg than suggested- about twice as much as recommended as this is what gives the donuts much flavor. Without the strong nutmeg taste- it kinda just taste like cake muffins. Thanks SO MUCH for this recipe! Will use again and again. BTW, this is a good one for potlucks too! :)
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2010-05-29T11:46:16.65
helpfulCount:
0

Display Name:

photo:

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
These are great! I didn't have any nutmeg, so I used cinnamon as a substitute and it was great. I didn't fill each muffin cup to the top and I got 24 out of the batch, and they were still wonderful. My husband and I found that they were way too sugary when we rolled the entire muffins in butter and the sugar/cinnamon mixture, so we started just dipping the muffin tops instead. Additionally, I made a chocolate sauce (1 C. chocolate chips, 1 C. butter, melted and mixed together, then added 1/4 C. heavy whipping cream) to simulate a real chocolate-glazed donut. It's a great sauce and cools/firms nicely on the muffins.

country:
None
text:
First off I do not have mini muffin tins, so I used my regular muffin pan, which I am sure makes all the difference in the world. You need the buttery cinnamon sugary flavor in each bite otherwise these are just plain muffins. I also wanted to let reviewers know that I subbed canola oil for the butter in the batter and my muffins turned out fine. I doubled the recipe, but only added 3/4 tsp of nutmeg do to what other reviewers said, and I wish I had used the whole amount. But, I will try these again when I have a mini muffin tin to see if that will make it a 5 star recipe. EDIT: I have been drizzling these with maple syrup and then microwaving for 15 seconds. Taste similar to a coffee cake. Yum!
